name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 18 July 2019.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I have some communications. One concerns a fact that saddened and saddened us greatly, because there was the sudden death of one of our colleagues, the Portuguese MEMBER André Jorge Dionísio Bradford, who deprived his country, his party and the European Parliament of his personal and political commitment. He was very young, he was 48 years old. A life dedicated to civic commitment in the defense of democracy, in the enhancement of the political autonomy of the Azores, recognized and praised by all for its kindness, for its oratory, for its solid cultural and personal training of great ethical importance. He was recently elected to the European Parliament and had a new and important challenge ahead of him. Recalling André's memory and example, I express my deep regret and solidarity with his family, friends, the Socialist and Democratic Group and all my colleagues in the European Parliament.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: There is also another painful communication, because last week there were serious floods in Europe which affected a large area of south-east and central Spain and caused rivers to flood in large areas of the provinces of Valencia, Alicante, Murcia, Almería, Granada, Albacete and Madrid. Six people lost their lives, tens of thousands were forced to leave their homes and workplaces. On behalf of this House, I would like today to express our closeness and condolences to the victims and their families and, at the same time, to express our deepest sympathy and affection to all those affected by these floods. I would also like to convey our recognition to the tireless work of the emergency services, to the incredible effort produced by the rescue teams of the various special forces and to all the volunteers who are participating in the rescue activities. It is in memory of our colleague and the victims in Spain, also as an act of closeness to their families, that I invite you to stand up and respect a minute's silence. (Parliament was standing and observing a minute's silence)

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Mr President, last week a prisoner exchange took place between Ukraine and Russia, and I think much to our joy Oleg Sentsov and 24 Ukrainian marines have been freed. But I think this House also agrees that this prisoner exchange should not come at the detriment of finding justice for the victims of MH17. Handing over one of the key suspects, Mr Tsemakh, to Moscow was very painful, not only for the victims but also for their families. So I hope this House can send a signal that of course we stand in solidarity with Ukraine, but we also expect them to live up to the UN resolution on finding the perpetrators who are responsible for shooting down MH17.  (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The Minutes of the sitting of 18 July 2019 and the texts adopted have been distributed.  Are there any comments?

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Cyprus is currently surrounded by the Turkish navy. At the same time it has installed platforms for the discovery of hydrocarbons in the Exclusive Economic Zone of Cyprus, which is also European. At the same time, Mr Tsavousoglou threatens daily with the settlement of the city of Famagusta, which is protected by resolutions of the United Nations and the European Parliament. The European Parliament must take action. The European Council has decided to take sanctions against Turkey. The European Parliament must move in this direction.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I was asking if there are any comments on the Minutes. If they are not there, the Minutes are approved. (The Minutes of the previous sitting were approved)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Another announcement concerns the election of the European Ombudsman. Ladies and gentlemen, on 30 August 2019, a call for nominations was published in the Official Journal with a view to the election of the European Ombudsman. The deadline for submitting applications is 30 September 2019. On September 4th you received an email from me with more information. I would like to point out that, pursuant to Rule 231(2) of the Rules of Procedure, each candidacy must have the support of at least forty Members representing at least two Member States. Each Member may support only one candidacy. If a Member supports multiple nominations, none of these choices will be taken into account. Once a candidacy is forwarded to the President, it is no longer possible to withdraw or add supporting signatures. Once the deadline for submitting applications has expired, I will assess the eligibility of the candidates and forward their candidature to the Committee on Petitions, which will hold the candidates' hearings at the beginning of December. These hearings will be open to all Members. The election of the new Ombudsman to this House is currently scheduled for plenary in December 2019.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The final draft agenda, established by the Conference of Presidents pursuant to Rule 157 of the Rules of Procedure, was distributed at its meeting on Thursday 12 September 2019. The following amendments have been tabled: No amendments are proposed on Monday. On Tuesday, following consultations with the political groups, I would like to present to the House the following proposal to amend the final draft agenda for Tuesday. The title of the Commission statement on the Eu ropean Union's common position ahead of the UNITED Nations Climate Action Summit in New York should be changed to 'Preparation for the Climate Action Summit and the New York Sustainable Development Goals Summit'. Are there any objections? (Parliament agreed to the proposal) On Tuesday (continued) The Group of the Greens/European Democrats and the Confederal Group of the European United Left/Nordic Green Left called for the debate on the Council and Commission statements on forest fires in the Amazon region to be concluded with a resolution, which will be voted on thursday morning. I give the floor to Mr Beazley. Mr Lamberts, Chairman, to make the request on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Green Group.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what is happening in the Amazon - because we are not talking about it in the past, we are talking about it in the present - massive forest fires in the Amazon region are a global problem. It is perfectly legitimate for this Parliament not only to debate it, but to speak out. What I fear very much is that, if we simply debate the situation without drawing the conclusions, I already see a number of people in the Amazon, the proponents of agribusiness, rubbing their hands and saying: finally, Europe is a tiger that does not bite. I therefore think it is important that we conclude the debate with a resolution which clearly states, from our point of view, the consequences that the European Union should draw if Brazil remains in its position today, which is essentially to say that there is no problem and that, ultimately, the Europeans only have to meddle in what concerns them. I think the case of the Amazon is a concern for all of us. It is not just a world heritage, it is an essential part of the fight against climate change and we cannot leave the current situation without consequences. I therefore ask you to vote on Thursday on a resolution by this Parliament which clearly states what consequences we intend to draw from the situation.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: – I’m sorry, my card doesn’t work, but I voted for. The card doesn’t work.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The ID and GUE/NGL Groups have requested that the debate and vote on the report by Mr De Gucht be held on be taken into account. The appointment of the President of the European Central Bank (Christine Lagarde) is postponed until the October I part-session in order to allow Ms Lagarde to be present. I give the floor to Mr Beazley. Bay to submit the ID group request.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the debate and vote scheduled for mrs Lagarde tomorrow were long-planned. This is obviously an essential debate and Mrs Lagarde has told us very late that she is being held back by bonds in Washington and that she will not be present. Some now claim that his hearing before the Committee on Economic Affairs would be sufficient, of course not. Too often, our Parliament is seen as a mere chamber for recording decisions that are taken elsewhere and in opacity. Today we add humiliation. It is a mark of contempt for the only European institution that has the legitimacy of universal suffrage.  The governance of the ECB is obviously fundamental. The policy of the strong euro, the policy to fight inflation are not without consequences, as we all know, on European employment and exports. This requires a real debate with the principal interested party. Our group therefore asks Mrs Lagarde to have the courtesy to come and debate before the European Parliament and, of course, therefore calls for the postponement of the vote and debate scheduled for tomorrow.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: Mr President, I absolutely do not agree with Mr Bay's argument and, as he mentions the procedure, I would like to point out that the procedure provides for a hearing of the candidate by the competent committee of the European Parliament, namely the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. This hearing took place, Mrs Lagarde made herself available to debate long hours with us and therefore, from that point of view - the rules were respected and these rules stipulate that, in fact, the vote will then be put to the plenary. Nevertheless, I would like to draw the plenary's attention to the fact that Mrs Lagarde has shown that, in principle, she agrees to come to the plenary, which the rules do not oblige her to do.  I think that if this Parliament wants to take this opportunity to improve its profile by having a debate with the candidate for the presidency of the Central Bank, that is a good thing. Mrs Lagarde, I think, had good reason to be in Washington: the General Assembly of the International Monetary Fund is preparing and so I do not take her absence here as a sign of disrespect. However, it is true that if tomorrow the debate cannot be held in its presence, it does not make much sense to hold it.  So, for reasons quite opposite to Mr Bay's, I think it might make sense - but only if it is consensual in this Parliament - to hold the debate and vote in October I, but if we want to present this as an act of defiance towards Mrs Lagarde, then obviously we do not agree with those arguments.  But I think the reason why we have to do it is a reason for the stature of this Parliament. Leading the debate on mrs Lagarde's appointment without Mrs Lagarde makes no sense and if we want to have a debate on the monetary policy of the Union, then that is something else, this request was not made at the Conference of Presidents and it is not the one we are making today either.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, I wanted to clarify the request of our group of the European Unitarian Left. Article 130 of the internal regulation specifies that the appointment of the President of the Central Bank must take place within two months of her hearing. However, his hearing took place on 4 September. So we have until 4 November to appoint the President of the European Central Bank and we have two sessions in October. This could allow us to have a calm and healthy debate with Mrs Lagarde, as can be expected from a monetary policy and a new President of the European Central Bank. I remember her hearing where she said that the European Central Bank had listened to the market for far too long and that it was time to listen to the peoples of Europe. Well, we are here, dear friends, representatives of the European peoples, and it is time for the European Central Bank to listen to us, because it has listened to the market for far too long. I cannot imagine, dear friends and colleagues, that you would refuse a debate in the presence of Mrs Lagarde on her appointment to a body which we know is essential for the future of our planet and also for the future of peoples. I encourage you to ask for this debate with her and in her presence.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: – On the main board the votes against appear as abstentions, so there is an error, while on the display it is right. That is why Members do not understand what has happened.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the There is a predicament in the Chamber that there has also been an electronic confusion in the Greens' motion on whether we are upsetting the Amazon issue with a resolution – again, it was not plausible whether the electronically displayed result actually corresponded to the vote in the Chamber. I would ask you to have this vote repeated, because it is not acceptable for us to fail here because of technical problems.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: As far as the debate on the Gualtieri report is concerned, the results are: 175 in favour, 274 against, 10 abstentions. The agenda remains unchanged. With regard to the request concerning the debate on the Amazon region, the results are: in favour 192, against 228, abstentions 13. On Tuesday (continued) The Renew Group called for the resolution concluding the debate on the Council and Commission statements on foreign electoral interference and disinformation in national and European democratic processes to be postponed until the first October part-session. I give the floor to those who wish to support this request.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, it’s pretty straightforward. I think it is fine for us to have the debate, but clearly the draft resolution needs a bit more time. It is a very controversial and sensitive topic and we need to get it right. So let’s have the debate this time and work on the resolution for the next session.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Mr President, this initiative came from the S&D Group and I am very happy to see that there is a big majority in this House wanting to put this on the agenda. If it is necessary, in order to make sure we are united by setting up a special committee next week, we can live with the postponement. But I hope the outcome is not that we suddenly drop the case. So with that, we are in favour of having the debate tomorrow and the vote next week.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Following a good tradition of commemorating special anniversaries in this House in a form of debate and resolution, on the occasion of the eightieth anniversary of the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact – some call it the Hitler-Stalin Pact – we propose holding a debate with a resolution, just as we did with a broad consensus ten years ago. I think that the consequences of this pact have been fatal for the whole continent and are still partly felt today. I think that is appropriate for the sad reason that we are having a debate on this point with a resolution.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to emphasise that we retain the title that is in the plenary agenda: ‘The importance of European remembrance for the future of Europe’. Secondly, we kindly ask you to consider that we present and vote on a resolution in the October I plenary session. It is a very sensitive and important topic, and we would like to have enough time to work properly on the resolution.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: . In accordance with Article 314 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, I propose that, following submission by the Council, there should be a full debate. I say this because the Group of the Greens/European Free Europe had requested that the presentation by the Council on the general budget for the financial year 2020 be replaced by the Council and Commission statements on the 2020 budget. I propose that there should be not only a presentation by the Council, but also a full debate, with the plenary engaged. (Parliament agreed to the request) (The order of business was thus established)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the state of the EU's forests (2019/2807(SDR)).

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: miembro de la Comisión. – Señora presidenta, la Comisión Europea, al igual que este Parlamento, quiere expresar su solidaridad con todos los afectados por las recientes lluvias torrenciales, inundaciones y riadas que han padecido diversas regiones españolas, y trasladar su pésame a las familias de los fallecidos en las mismas y sumarse al agradecimiento a todas las autoridades, cuerpos de seguridad, protección civil y voluntarios, que no han escatimado esfuerzo alguno para paliar los efectos de esta catástrofe.  I am taking this point this afternoon on behalf of my colleague Commissioner Hogan. I want to thank you for the opportunity to contribute to this issue and I welcome the interest of Parliament in forests.  Forests, covering 40% of the European Union’s land surface, are a precious resource for our society, environment and economy and must play a very important role in addressing the sustainability challenges ahead. They are also affected by climate change and associated extreme events like storms or forest fires, which generate additional management challenges. In April this year, Commissioner Hogan organised a European Union conference on forests where we had the opportunity to discuss in depth the current challenges of the European Union’s forests and the forest-based sector. This was a very fruitful event, which had the participation of all relevant stakeholders: policymakers, administrators, researchers, forest—owner representatives, the forest industry, environmental NGOs and representatives of our civil society. The conference confirmed the growing relevance and importance of forests and the forest-based sector in the context of the Paris Agreement, the global biodiversity targets and achieving the SDGs, while also underpinning the importance of forests for new and future-proof economic opportunities in rural areas. Forests and forest-based products are crucial for achieving carbon neutrality by 2050, by constituting carbon sinks and by substituting fossil-based materials, as proposed in the political guidelines of the President-elect. You have asked the Commission to present an assessment of the situation of European Union forests. Let me start by saying that forest policy is primarily the responsibility of the Member States. This is well reflected in the European Union forest strategy and the recent Council conclusions of March 2019 on the review of the strategy that confirmed the subsidiarity—based approach on forestry policy at European Union level.  In the last few years, forests across the European Union have been increasingly subject to several extreme events such as storms, droughts and pests – often seen as consequences of climate change – which are responsible for great losses in the forest economy and the associated ecosystems. The recent large-scale bark beetle outbreaks in many European countries add to the effects of forest fires, storms and windstorms and other pests. The Commission chairs dedicated expert groups – the Standing Forestry Committee, the Coordination Group for Biodiversity and Nature, the Forest Fires Expert Group – to address these issues and facilitate regular exchange of information and good practice between Member States and the Commission. For instance, recent dedicated discussions have addressed the bark beetle situation in the Standing Forestry Committee in December 2018 and guidance on fire prevention-oriented management of forested landscapes in the Forest Fires Expert Group in November 2018. Forest protection and resilience will also be discussed in next week’s Coordination Group for Biodiversity and Nature. An example of the magnitude of impacts is the large-scale mortality of Norway spruce forests in central Europe caused by bark beetle outbreaks, estimated at 80-82 million m3 for 2018. For Germany, the losses of forests as a result of bark beetle outbreak and the drought during the last two years is estimated to have resulted in more than 100 000 hectares of forests being seriously damaged. Concerning forest fires, according to the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) more than 300 000 hectares of forest burnt down by early September 2019, in 1 880 fires. This figure is more than 60 000 hectares larger than the 2008-2018 average. In total, it is estimated that up to four million hectares of forested areas in Europe are affected by forest damage. This damage is causing significant effects in European forest ecosystems, within and outside Natura 2000, and in the forest-based industry. The current situation on the European roundwood market is beyond comparison: driven by damaged wood from droughts, heat, windstorms and floods, and bark beetle infestation, the market is flooded in terms of volume, and market prices are dropping. The situation is far from optimal from the point of view of climate change mitigation through harvested wood products. In order to support forests and the forest sector’s needs, the European Union Forest Strategy achieved the alignment of the European Union funding instruments in support of a commonly agreed set of objectives and priorities, building on the key principles of sustainable forest management, multifunctionality and resource efficiency.  The common agricultural policy (CAP) is the main source of financial support for European Union forests. The planned public expenditure for 2014-2020 is about EUR eight billion, spread across 90% of the rural development programmes. Other EU funds, such as the cohesion policy, the civil protection mechanism, the LIFE financial instrument, or the research framework programme, consistently support the European Union objectives for forests. Support for the prevention of damage to forests caused by fires, natural disasters and extreme events, and for the restoration of production potential, is also available to Member States through the European Union’s rural development policy. For the period 2014-2020, fire and natural disaster prevention and restoration account for over 20% of the planned CAP expenditure on forests, including EUR 1.7 billion for prevention, and EUR 700 million for restoration. Additionally, an amount of EUR 1.5 billion is programmed for ensuring the long-term resilience of forests. The European Union civil protection mechanism has also been providing ample technical support to disaster prevention and preparedness, and means to help fight disasters such as forest fires. This mechanism has recently been strengthened, for example by establishing a European reserve of capacities that includes firefighting planes and helicopters. Moreover, we are also committing substantial support for research and innovation in the forest-based sector under Horizon 2020, including for the protection of forests and new practices and approaches to enhance forest resilience. We expect that the budget will be substantially increased under Horizon Europe.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The forest is an important climate protection ist in Europe; this is particularly true if the forest is also managed and the wood can replace other products such as steel and cement. It is also important for a large economic sector, for recovery and for biodiversity. The forest is in poor condition in many countries in Europe, for example in the Czech Republic, Slovakia, France, Germany and southern Scandinavia. The cause is obviously the extreme drought of the last two years and thus the spread of pests such as the bark beetle. So, in short, a key climate activist is at risk, probably because of climate change. That is why we must, of course, help – everyone at their level – above all on the ground in the Member States, but also where we, as the European Union, have competences. We need to look at financial support. This is, for example, the second pillar of agricultural policy. However, it is not appropriate to drastically reduce the second pillar. We as a Parliament will certainly not accept that. But it is also a question of interpreting rules in competition law and in other areas. We really have a disaster here – and everyone must be aware of that. All those who talk about the interpretation of rules must do so accordingly unbureaucratically now. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Unfortunately, we only have the debate on the agenda. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats also wanted a resolution. I hope that in the next few days we will be able to talk about not only debating here, but also preparing concrete actions, such as a resolution in the next plenary. We must send out the signal: we care about the forest and we support all those who care about the forest.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D- Madam President, we are not going to hide it: the European Union has its share of responsibility for global deforestation. We Europeans are responsible because we import a lot of wood from all over the world. We are also responsible because we continue to import or use many products containing palm oil. Some countries, including France, even continue to promote it as a fuel, while palm oil cultivation is an environmental disaster and its use is three times more harmful to the climate than fossil diesel. We are responsible, but we can act, we must act. It is our duty to enhance the European forest resource with a real strategy of protecting and restoring forests. We must also set clear rules for sustainable management of these forests. Finally, a personal remark. We would be much more credible if, in the international free trade agreements that Europe signs - as with Mercosur, for example - we put binding clauses such as respect for the environment.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: On behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, Commissioner Cañete, the European forest sometimes does well and sometimes quite poorly. The reason why this is the case is perhaps because there is nothing like a European forest, we only have European forests in plural and some of them are doing quite well and others are doing worse. In order for us to understand what is actually going on, perhaps we should look at what has happened in recent years in both Canada and Russia. There have been huge forest fires in both countries. In fact, Canada's forest resources are already negative in ecological terms precisely because huge forest fires have released so much CO2 into the air. The reason for this is simple: when nature starts a forest fire, there is no way to put out it. There are no forest roads, there is no possibility of extinguishing, which is why the problem remains permanent. In Russia, we have exactly the same situation: in July, four million hectares of forest were burned there and no one was able to put out. The fact that we take care of the forests requires forest roads. It requires what Donald Trump said a little erdually that we're going to go for a bit of a rake. It's not that small a rake, it's really hard work. But without forest management, we will not solve this problem. Nor is we the bark beetle problem, known as the book-workshop, which is currently spreading quite badly in southern Europe.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, thank you for this debate on European forests because we talk quite often about forests outside Europe, but I think it’s very important to talk about the state of our forests within the EU as well, especially because forests are very crucial for climate. They are a natural carbon sink and they are key for biodiversity – and on both matters Europe is not performing well.  First of all on climate: 40% of our current renewables come from biomass and in the Commission’s own impact assessment for the LULUCF Directive, it clearly states that we expect a decline in our sink in the future until 2030, and a decline in the sink is the same effect as higher emissions. So we have to look and do better there also, in forestry as a sink. But also on biodiversity: the Environmental Assessment Agency clearly states that the state of our forests is only at 25% of the favourable status in Natura 2000, in protected areas. So we expect action from the Commission in its climate law to improve the natural carbon sinks and a binding biodiversity strategy for 2030 in order to improve our forests for climate and biodiversity.

name: Teuvo HAKKARAINEN
text: On behalf of the ID Group. – Mr President, there was a small mistake, but Mr Torvalds has already left. It would be good to take it from there, and I will. Finland has invested in forest management for over 100 years, and as a result, forests grow more in Finland than ever before, for that very reason. In forests, for example, forest roads have been made to get the forests managed, as well as to prevent fires. We are at the same latitude as Russia, Canada and Sweden. There were large forest fires in Sweden not long ago, but the Finns managed to prevent them. Because Finland lives in the forest, it also knows how to manage its forests so that they grow. Now that we are concerned about the forests of Europe, come and see how it is handled in Finland.  Personal experience I have of it. At the age of 16, I have already gone to forest work and I have seen how forests are grown, managed and used and how diversity is preserved and everything is in order. So welcome to Finland to see how things are done. And not that from where these problems are, we are given regulations that know how to do it.

name: Robert ROWLAND
text: blue-card question. – The question I had was whether there was a slight contradiction here between what we are advocating as a House, in protecting the European forests, and the European Union’s policy of biodiesel and biomass in its energy complex, where we’re advocating a green policy which causes the destruction of Indonesian rainforests – natural tropical rainforests – and also the loss of precious lives, of orang-utans, for example, and at the same time ... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Hakkarainen, there is a blue-card request from Mr Rowland. Would you accept the blue card? Will you take the question? Yes.

name: Teuvo HAKKARAINEN
text: – Thank you, I will answer the question.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you sir, it is for 30 seconds, and that does not sound like a question to the previous speaker but you have had your 30 seconds. Mr Hakkarainen, do you wish to respond to his point rather than his question? It is up to you, sir. He has finished speaking. You have the floor if you wish. Please could you stand up?

name: Teuvo HAKKARAINEN
text: answer to the blue card question. – I will only answer the question.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: You are going to stand up and answer the question? I wasn’t clear. You are not going to answer the question? Thank you for your clarity. Mr Rowland, you heard the response.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The state of our forests should become one of the key challenges for decades to come. In recent years, we have been observing with concern the process of destroying forests: fires, illegal logging, parasites, even a bark beetle. Globally, the area of forests has decreased over the last ten years, although fortunately the Union is not doing badly against this background. In Poland, the area of forests is steadily increasing from 20% of the country's area in 1946 to 30% today. And we are planning further growth. Polish State Forests are a very good example of forest management. I think we should exchange good practices. Every year, 500 million trees are planted in Poland. In total, it is almost 60 thousand hectares of renewals and afforestation. Unfortunately, the Union often does not encourage Member States to afforestation, and that was the case, I ask you, in the case of LULUCF in the previous term of office, when the role of active forest management in reducing emissions was underestimated. So it's worth exchanging good practices. Polish State Forests are an example of reasonable, proper management at a world-class level.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Before I give the floor to the next speaker, just to clarify for new Members of the House that the blue card means a 30-second question, and the person to whom you address the question has 30 seconds to answer. I think that is important for information.

name: João FERREIRA
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, the vulnerability of the forest has concrete expression in the recurrence and size of fires, in the predominance of exotic species, in the occurrence of pests, in the insufficient yield of forest producers. Among the causes of this vulnerability are the lack of investment and the lack of people. These two are inseparable from the policies and guidelines of the European Union. The Common Agricultural Policy, underfinancing, privatisation and dismantling of public services, including agrarian and forestry extension services, the dominance of monopolies over the timber sector, asphyxiated thousands of small producers, compromised the multifunctionality of the forest, promoted forest deplanning and rural abandonment, voting to abandon large areas of the territory. Where there used to be people, there's fire today! We have long advocated the need for more investment in the forest, we advocate the need for a Community approach to disaster prevention, with adequate resources from the Community budget, which is depending on the implementation. And forest defence also requires other agricultural, rural and commercial development policies, in addition to ending the limitations imposed on public investment.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, Greece experienced a great tragedy in Mati last year with 102 dead. This year, as every year, he experienced large fires in Evia, Eastern Attica, Zakynthos, Loutraki and elsewhere. Governments are changing, but EU planning remains. The planning of the commercialisation of land, business action in forests, the criminal nudity of the state mechanism with 1.1 billion euro cuts over the last decade in forest firefighting and forest protection. With the so-called 'rescEU' the shortcomings in resources, personnel, infrastructure and funding in each Member State are not only not covered, but are, on the contrary, legitimised and justified. This is based on the commitment of part of the Member State's operational capacities with limited funding for aircraft purchases and repairs, which are considered by the European Union as a total cost. The mechanism sends forces, as already proven, 'after a holiday', if they are not employed elsewhere and only in 'extremely critical situations'. We demand here and now adequate state funding with permanent staff, full rights, excellent equipment in each country to meet all real needs and no business action in forests.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Indeed, as you said, Commissioner, the state of Europe's forests is, in part, threatening. The bark beetle is spreading, and probably also due to climate change, storms are increasing, also for example last autumn in my region. And yet forests and trees have a very prominent role in climate protection and biodiversity: trees and forests are like a green lung, and for this and to do so, sustainable forestry is of paramount importance. Forests can only play the role of climate protection if the wood is also harvested, that is, if the forest is also used, and if, in the end, the wood is also used to produce building materials or also to produce energy. This commitment by forest farmers to sustainability and sustainable forestry must be rewarded, and we must do everything we can to get the forest farmers to keep the European forest alive, to preserve it sustainably, so that this forest can also fulfil its many functions in the fight against climate change. I think that this can be done within the framework of the second pillar of the common agricultural policy, and I too am very concerned about the proposed cuts in the second pillar. Above all, however, I believe that we should also consider whether we should not also introduce new instruments in the context of the debate on climate change in order to sustainably preserve the forests of Europe and maintain its role in the fight against climate change.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in our forests is increasingly at risk and the European Union must once again lead the way in the fight against this emergency. So much has been done, and it is useful to remember, also thanks to the common agricultural policy. Over the last twenty years, we have seen an increase in our forest area equal to the size of Portugal, a sign of a European strategy that needs to be improved but which has already produced important results. However, Commissioner, we cannot stop. The cuts in the common agricultural policy in the Commission's proposal mean, in some countries, a heavy reduction in rural development programmes: in some countries it will be 25 % cut, and this is certainly an unacceptable step backwards. Our farmers and foresters must be the protagonists of the challenge and take cover for the problems of our forests. At the same time, action must also be taken with regard to the large timber exporting countries by establishing an efficient certification programme enabling safeguard clauses to be activated. We are faced with a real climate emergency: only a strong and united European Union will be able to give our citizens the courageous and no longer postponed answers that await us.

name: Nicolae ŞTEFĂNUȚĂ
text: – Commissioner, there is a large part of the virgin forests in Europe in Romania. While forests should be protected for their essential role in preserving biodiversity, mass deforestation in protected areas continues. The Birds and Habitats Directives are constantly violated. According to a report by Agent Green, more than 3,600 hectares of secular forest have been lost in Romania in the last six years. In the natural parks were cut 1.2 million cubic meters of wood. Fires are, of course, important, but they don't tell the whole story of the European forest. Agent Green, ClientEarth and Euronatur submitted a request for help to the Commission to stop forest logging in protected natural areas. Commissioner, what we have on the sheet is not identical to what we actually have. How, however, will you really implement these European rules in the interests of the European forest?

name: Anna DEPARNAY-GRUNENBERG
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for I would like to remind you that the forest is slowly growing. It follows the unfathomable rhythms of nature. Of course, we in Europe need to develop silvicultural, our forestry needs to become closer to nature, more resilient, more adapted to climate change. We must also protect our special biotopes, and wilderness must be given more space. We must also keep in mind that we need sustainable production of this incredibly valuable ecological raw material wood. But it will not be possible to compensate for the entire ecological iniquity committed by our growth-driven industrial society only in the forest and through the forest. That is sometimes a bit of the debate. We will not be able to meet the insatiable energy needs of the energy forest – that is, the criticism of biomass. We will not be able to see the forest unilaterally as a CO2 sink. Nor can we change the whole loss of biodiversity through a new forest policy. Agricultural policy is wrong and trade policy is also wrong in order to really do something about it. We cannot do all this simultaneously and quickly. The forest grows slowly and can only be changed slowly. Our children will judge us against this.

name: Sylvia LIMMER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In the Commission's communications, I keep reading headlines such as 'EU measures to protect forests' or 'Restoration of the forest'. Are you not afraid of your own ridiculousness? After all, it is precisely the EU that, with its energy transition, which is free of meaning and evidence, contributes to the sustainable destruction of forests – by the way, the only sustainability of the energy transition in relation to forests. Let us look at Germany, a country with more than 33,000 wind turbines, many of them at wooded altitudes. But what cares about the self-proclaimed forest and environmentalists – forest destruction for a good cause. Here, it is not the bark beetle that is the biggest pest, but the energy transition: for example, 70 planned wind farm parks with about 500 wind turbines in the UNESCO Nature Park Odenwald, the Münsterwald, the Reinhardswald with trees up to 800 years old. The list is long. Hence my urgent recommendation: leave sensible forest management to local professionals and not to ideology-driven EU technocrats! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. I have listened to your intervention. You started by saying that it is ridiculous to look at the situation of forests in the European Union. I, on the contrary, believe that we need to discuss and take action. What do you think should be done if we are talking about a European Union, an internal market, a union of states? What do you think, that it should be left to everyone to do what they want with the forests, or do we need to look here and find specific measures to improve the situation of forests?

name: Sylvia LIMMER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I do not think you have understood what I have said. It is ridiculous that an EU that, with its energy transition and its policies, leads to precisely this destruction of forests, which is then lamented in the end, is playing itself up to the saviour of those very forests.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Dear Madam President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable Members, the debate is undoubtedly timely, especially with a view to the last few months in which we have witnessed large, large-scale forest fires worldwide that have incinerated thousands of hectares of forests. However, it is important that we are not alone in this debate, as unfortunately often happens in this chamber. While forest management is a policy within the competences and obligations of the Member States, it is important to note once again and repeat the European Union's forest strategy, which should serve as a talking point for coordinating national policies as well. About 50% of Europe's area is forest areas, which accounts for about 5% of the world's forest fund. While europe is not such a large and significant forest fund globally, the cliché that they are the green lungs of the planet and we need to take care of them is true. Although global trends are for forest areas to decrease, in the Union they continued to grow and increased by around 11 million hectares by 2010. I believe that everyone present in the chamber agrees on the vital importance that forests have on nature conservation and biodiversity, climate change mitigation and the fight to save individual regions. It is important to protect them from illegal logging and pillaging. I call for the use of all the tools, especially the personal example.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Madam President, forestry strategy, if implemented properly, should be good for the environment, it should be good for local communities and it should be good for rural economies. We have a situation in my own Member State of Ireland where government policy has ensured that the forestry strategy does none of those things. Now that is not the fault of the European institutions, but the commitment that I would like from you, Commissioner, and the Commission this evening is that the EU won’t fund that policy and the strategy that has seen widespread planting of non-indigenous Sitka spruce, in some cases actually on peat bogland, whereby the actual planting of forests is doing more environmental damage than if they were not planted in the first place. Secondly, Commissioner, I want you to answer the contradiction that lies at the heart of the Commission’s position in talking about a forestry strategy while at the same time giving a blank cheque to the Brazilian authorities to burn thousands, and hundreds of thousands, of acres of the most important forestry network in the world. That is a question that needs to be answered this evening, Commissioner.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Carthy, we are, as you know, having a debate tomorrow on that very important issue.

name: Jessica POLFJÄRD
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on We all agree that forests play a key role in the climate change transition. The Commission's report shows that parts of Europe's forests are in trouble and have lost resistance due to the drought. This is a problem that needs to be taken seriously and must be followed. But let me be clear. The solution is not regulation at EU level, but the eu Member States' self-determination over the forest issue must be safeguarded and maintained. Those who actively use the forest are also those who sit on the knowledge of how we continue to manage the forest best.  But there are two things that we can do at European level. The first is to modernise and update the 2013 forest strategy, as significant progress has been made and the outside world has changed since then. Secondly, we can ensure that EUROPEAN legislation takes advantage of the opportunities offered by forests and forest products.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: – Madam President, the European Union’s forests are classified among the most valuable natural areas in the word. The Carpathian Forest is one example. Unfortunately, what is happening there nowadays raises the question: is it a second Białowieża case? The Polish Minister of the Environment decided on the mass logging of the forest. The White Carpathians initiative, WWF Poland and the Polish Natural Heritage Foundation are alarmed. The logging site covers Natura 2000 areas and violates EU law, namely the Habitats and Birds Directives. It’s high time for EU action on this matter, and for the strong voice of the Commission and the Court of Justice to be heard.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Yes, the extreme drought has put a massive strain on our forests in recent years. The bark beetle has exploded, and if I look at the figures from my state – Bavaria – twenty million cubic metres of bark beetle wood have been cut in the last five years, at an average price of 25 euros per hectare. Half a billion euros loss for our Bavarian forest owners! Money that is urgently needed to actually bring forest conversion forward. The forest as we know it today is the loser of climate change. In order to be fit for the future, we need a sustainably managed forest instead of excessive environmental laws. We need a sustainable raw material strategy for the use of wood in all areas of life. I could also imagine including bark beetle wood in public construction projects. Only a managed forest stores CO2 and protects the climate, and we must all be aware of this.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, our forests are in peril and this summer's fires bear witness to this awareness. When you look at it, you lose the equivalent of 800 forest football fields per hour, that's huge. Mr Caete, your communication is very complete on the observation, but still not proactive enough on the proposals, which suggest a lot of dialogue and voluntary commitments, but too few, far too few binding measures.  I would like to make you some of them, especially on wood energy. It is absolutely necessary to exclude now, and not in 2023, wood energy from EUROPEAN renewable energy legislation.  We know that 80 per cent of the world's deforestation is due to intensive agriculture, so we need to stop importing meat, soybeans, palm oil that contribute to deforestation in the Amazon and Indonesia.  Finally, it is essential to empower indigenous peoples and local communities to effectively protect their forests, because they are the best custodians of them.  So there are a lot of things to do, Mr Caete, and we are waiting for concrete proposals.

name: Hynek BLAŠKO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the forests of Central Europe are dying. This is due to a combination of several factors. Firstly, human over-care, drought and disaster caused by the spruce calf. Human over-care is that so-called no-interference zones have been created in national parks. Thus, the spruce calf was given absolutely favorable conditions for reproduction by not even attacking trees in these zones. In the Czech Republic, once beautiful forests in šumava and partly in the Bavarian Forest are destroyed. What a sad sight it is to see devastated forests. I propose that the European Commission urgently address the situation and take strong measures to prevent the effects of human stupidity, albeit professionally, and lift the ban on the extraction of infested trees in non-intervention zones. Greens, what do you say? (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the Blue Card (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: the question asked by raising the blue card. – Madam President, I do not want there to be a Czech-Czech debate, but Mr Blaško has raised the proposal for the European Commission to intervene in the Member States. Do you believe, colleague, that the Czech Ministry of the Environment, Czech forestry, is not able to make its own decisions? You really think someone's going to tell us to do something? I am not against sharing good practice, but I trust our foresters, I trust our environmental experts.

name: Hynek BLAŠKO
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Dear colleague, unlike you, I have disposed of the spruce calf and I see what happened to Šumava, I went there. Were you ever there when the beautiful woods were there? And since we can't handle ourselves, we need someone from the outside to advise us, because there's been so many specialists. Look at šumava, this is the result of their work.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, forests have an important impact on climate and environmental conditions, soil quality and agriculture, energy independence and accessibility, while also representing an important raw material resource. Fortunately, Europe is not threatened by excessive deforestation; in fact, the forest area on our continent is increasing, which is encouraging information.  But this does not mean that we use these forests well and manage them well. Differences between Member States are large, not only in terms of coverage of their territory by forests but also in terms of ownership. While most European forests are privately owned, in Croatia almost 80% are publicly owned and managed by a public company. The agreed objectives in future forest area management strategies must be common to us, but we must be careful to take into being specific to each Member State.  Thank you very much.

name: Alexis GEORGOULIS
text: Madam President, it does not make sense for the European Union not to have a common forestry policy. Forests, in addition to the natural wealth of a country, are also the lung of the whole planet. They create oxygen for all humans but also for animals. It is estimated that 43% of Europe's area consists of forests, which, in addition to the richness of ecosystems and the useful source of renewable energy they offer, have the capacity to absorb carbon dioxide emissions. European forests absorb 10% of these emissions. Rapid overheating, however, leads to deadly fires. This year, the average number of fires in the European Union has tripled. The European South – Greece, Italy, Spain and Portugal – literally ignites every summer with significant losses in natural wealth, animals and people. It is also predicted that this number will increase by 40% to 100% in recent years. I mean, we won't have forests to protect in a while. That is why we must act immediately as long as we can afford it. Why not take the great green wall in Africa as an example and follow it? We grew up in fear that climate change would be a problem that would concern one of the next generations and, ultimately, that generation is us.

name: Juan Ignacio ZOIDO ÁLVAREZ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you and congratulate you on your work at the head of the Energy and Climate Action portfolio. Thank you very much for your leadership in bringing the Paris Agreement to fruition and for your ambitious climate change goals. Forests are one of our greatest environmental assets. They help us protect soils from erosion, filter air, serve as habitat for numerous species and play a key role in combating climate change. We know a lot about this in Spain, the second-largest forested country in all of Europe. Spanish forests have made us the country of the European Union richest in biodiversity, and its 7.5 billion trees absorb 37% of the CO2 we emit. But at the same time, we are well aware that there is no landscape without landscaping. The good state of conservation and health of our forests depend on their relationship with the inhabitants of the rural world. That is why we must recognise the important economic and social role of forests in rural Europe. Forests are fundamental to combating depopulation, generating economic opportunities and employment in empty Spain. They give work to the timber industry and supply the necessary material for the generation of bioenergy. We therefore show our full rejection of the cuts proposed by the Commission for the CAP budget.

name: Nicolás GONZÁLEZ CASARES
text: – Mr President, as has been said, on the one hand, we pay for agricultural products that reduce forests in third countries and, on the other hand, in some areas of Europe the rural demographic decline causes the mountain to expand, with the consequent abandonment of traditional crops and extensive livestock, just as forest fires increase. Nor can we afford the progressive loss of our native forests, notably the Atlantics, which are biodiversity reserves. For example, in Galicia, the area of eucalyptus monoculture has doubled in twenty years. It is not a question of eliminating it, but it is about preventing its uncontrollability and promoting orderly management. From the European Union we have an obligation to promote a trade and international policy that curbs deforestation, but also, Commissioner, here in Europe, we must promote sustainable forest management, protect the traditional forest, combat rural depopulation, encourage extensive and sustainable livestock, while retaining the funds dedicated to the CAP, helping to maintain our forests and ecosystems in a healthier way.

name: Martin HOJSÍK
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, European forests, our natural resources, are at risk. They are threatened not only by the climate crisis, but also by developers, mismanagement, fires and deadly chemistry. Their devastation is detrimental to our entire society. We are in a climate emergency, and if we are to limit global warming below one and a half degrees and protect our biodiversity, we really need to protect forest ecosystems. We need rules that end blanket spraying with dangerous pesticides in forests that stop their pillaging, help their recovery, but also ensure that at least part, at least five per cent, of Europe's forests remain untouched, that they remain unaffected. It is a question of principle. Political interest or short-term economic interests must never prevail. We cannot forget that forests are not just a source of income, they are a source of life and biodiversity. We therefore need a new European strategy on forests, because their viability is the foundation of the future.

name: Saskia BRICMONT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, when we know that forest goods and services are involved in achieving 9 of the 17 sustainable development goals (food production, clean water supply, carbon capture and storage, biodiversity and, too often forgotten, reducing inequalities), interest in forests should really go back on the political agenda. In this regard, we welcome President von der Leyen's commitment to making achieving these goals a priority. But, if there is a reforestation policy, I remember above all a sentence from your communication: newly planted forests cannot replace primary forests. When there is destruction, they cannot be recreated. When there is a loss, it cannot be compensated. There is a lot of talk about the Amazon, it is obviously on the front page, but no less than 43% of the European territory is forested. So it's a key issue, we have to find the means. There are some within the framework of the common agricultural policy, but they are largely underutilized. Is the European Commission planning to promote it to member states? Finally, I repeat, with my colleagues: biomass is a fundamental issue and we know that there is a real aberration, a hypocrisy, to use it as a renewable energy source.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Speaking in this debate, I would like to emphasise that my country, Poland, is one of the leaders of the Union when it comes to sustainable, multifunctional forest management. It should also be added that this is a self-financing economy. The amount of timber harvested has doubled in the last thirty years, but without compromising forest resources in the country, as evidenced by the steady increase in forest area. Today, forestry in Poland is almost thirty percent. In this situation, it has become good that forests have finally been integrated by the May 2018 Regulation of Parliament and the Council into the climate and energy policy framework, which means that the removal of CO2 emissions from forests will finally be taken into account in the emission balances of individual EU countries. This will have a positive impact on forestry development after 2020. Unfortunately, climate change is adversely affecting forests in Europe: high temperatures, long periods of drought, snowless winters and extreme weather events such as hurricane winds, as well as pest infesting, including in particular the printer's bark beetle, are causing enormous damage, which requires the support of forest management. (The speaker agreed to respond to the questioning inflicted by raising the blue card (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Karen MELCHIOR
text: blue-card question. – Thank you very much, Mr Kuźmiuk, for your intervention. Having lived in Poland I know the importance of the Polish forest and I want to hear what you think the Polish Government and Poland is doing to protect the original, very important forest in Poland.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Thank you very much for this question. Indeed, a lot of misunderstandings have arisen around the State Forests in Poland in recent months, especially with regard to the issue of the printing bark beetle in the Białowieża Forest. But these figures, which I have just presented, show that Polish State Forests are carrying out exemplary forest management throughout the European Union. Moreover , and I would like to emphasise very strongly, this is a self-financing economy. Thank you very much.

name: Anne SANDER
text: "Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, forests precede peoples, deserts follow them," said Chateaubriand. If this is true in some parts of the world - and this summer's news has been sorely reminded - Europe is an exception in this regard, since the European forest stretches by one hectare every four seconds. It is an opportunity, but it is above all a great responsibility. In a context of intense heat wave, pest attack and wood diseases, we must redouble our efforts to ensure that our European forests are well managed and continue to play an economic, social and environmental role. Because the potential of European forests for the implementation of the Paris Agreement is extraordinary. However, we must allow ourselves to exploit our resources in full respect of sustainable development and the long-term growth of our forest heritage. While there is no common forestry policy, European policies can have an impact on national policies. Therefore, it seems to me essential, Commissioner, that the appropriations for the second pillar of the CAP be maintained for the next budgetary programme. They are essential to support forest owners in their sustainable forest management. We also believe that our research project needs to be mobilized to support adaptation to climate change.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, in its recent communication on forest protection, the Commission is considering additional regulatory measures to combat deforestation and better protect forests. So two questions. The first: do you intend to introduce binding regulations to ensure that products at risk to forests, such as products of intensive agriculture or products of mining, which are much less talked about and which are nevertheless a major cause of deforestation, and therefore that these products which are put on the EU market are not linked to deforestation and in what time frame? The second question: in order to make trade agreements a real lever against deforestation, do you envisage making the chapter "sustainable development" binding, with sanctions? I give you an example of this Canadian mining industry that uprooted no less than 195,000 trees in Turkey, ten times more than originally planned. How can we guarantee that the gold that is exploited by this company will not end up on the European market thanks to the CETA free trade agreement?

name: Norbert LINS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Our forest is a habitat, a supplier of wood, a place of recreation and a climate protector at the same time. But at the moment he is our patient, because heat, bark beetles and storms are more important to him than ever before. What our forest needs is care. We must not leave our hope against climate change alone, but must support it. According to Eurostat, Europe's forests absorb 10% of total EU greenhouse gas emissions every year. It is clear that a managed forest helps more against climate change than a forest that is left to its own devices. Why? On the one hand, wood permanently binds carbon as a building material, on the other hand, sustainable management primarily ensures healthy trees and thus maximum CO2 absorption capacity. Poorly managed forests, on the other hand, are the losers of climate change. Not only are they prone to droughts, but they are also a burden on pests. Therefore, sustainable and active forestry is a guarantee for healthy forests and their high CO2 absorption capacity. In order to be able to pursue these objectives, I am committed to further developing the European forest strategy, which calls for new, but above all healthy, forests. I look forward to working together. The Committee on Agriculture will also draw up proposals on this. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Lins, I would like to thank Mr Lins for his Would you agree with me that we should actually also use projects and European funds in the field of bark beetle research, for example from the Life programme or From Horizon 2020? Because I believe that biological agents are already well used, especially for the control of bark beetles, but these should be further researched. That is precisely the direction in which we must go together.

name: Norbert LINS
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Yes, I can answer the question very briefly and succinctly: I think this is a good idea, a good way of supporting this from the European side as well.

name: Eero HEINÄLUOMA
text: – Mr President, in order to do something sensible for forests, we must recognise that there is not a single forest in Europe, but that there are a wide variety of forests. Finland is the most forested country in Europe, more than 70% of the country's area is forests. Finland has always used forests, but it has done so in a wise, responsible way. Over the past 100 years, the number of forests in Finland has not decreased. They are indeed a source of recreation, they have been a source of prosperity and today we realise that they are hugely important for carbon sinks. The key is that we do sustainable forest management, and in that we can learn a lot from each other. What is important is that when the Commission considers the next steps, those countries that have managed their forests well will not be penalised when deciding, for example, on the future of carbon sinks.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Our next speaker is Simone Schmiedtbauer from green Styria in Austria, who, like many others, is making her maiden speech today.

name: Simone SCHMIEDTBAUER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Thank you very much for the nice introduction – yes, I come from Austria. 48% of our land, or almost 50%, is forest. Perhaps this is why we can understand why the forest is so important to me. Before we talk about the state of forests in Europe, however, I would like to make it very clear once again why forests are so important. In the fight against climate change, there is no greater supporter than our sustainable but managed forests. CO2 is stored in wood and also in wood products. The forest must be protected, but also useful for use. Saving CO2 and safeguarding more than three million jobs across Europe is what our forest can do. It is therefore very important to me that we approach the issue in a very objective way. The climate is changing. The pressure from pests and extreme weather events takes place. In view of this, the European Commission must respond and support our forest owners and the entire forestry sector. We therefore need a new, very strong EU forestry strategy that will continue to provide clarity in the future. We cannot accept cuts to the second pillar of the agricultural budget, which also supports our forest owners. We need public money to deal with the climate change consequences in our forests. I see the extension of the European Solidarity Fund as a very good solution to strengthen the backs of the forest owners concerned. You can be our partner in the future.

name: Adam JARUBAS
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Dear! Forests are one of the most important components of our ecosystems. Their condition depends on the ability to absorb and balance part of greenhouse gas emissions. The level of biodiversity also depends on the condition of forests. They are also part of an economy on which many European jobs are based, especially at local level. I agree with the Commission's assessment that, within the framework of the European Forestry Strategy, decisive action must be taken to help Member States, forest owners and managers to combat fires, cataclysms, diseases or forest pests. Today, we need to address this problem at European level, because individual action may not be as effective. Although I agree that this basic level should be the national level as closest as possible to this problem. This must be support at many levels, from coordination to mobilising adequate funds from the common agricultural policy or the Life programme, to supporting research and development. The forestry strategy should be reflected in Horizon Europe. The restoration of a forest substance is, on the one hand, the direction of action and, on the other hand, the strengthening of resistance to pests and atmospheric factors. Nor must we forget the infrastructure that is necessary in crisis cases and the support of the services that must be activated at Member State level in the case of fires or hurricanes.

name: Álvaro AMARO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we all know that the Treaties do not expressly mention the word 'forests'. We also know that in recent years the European institutions, Parliament, but of course the Commission, have been more active in managing this heritage. But I want to say here today that we believe that, despite the difficulties in managing such a different forest in the various countries, as agriculture is in so many countries that are part of the Union, it has been possible to make a Common Agricultural Policy. Here too, it has to be possible, at the very least, to make a common forestry strategy. That is why we say yes to environmental preservation and ecological balance, we say yes to the greater involvement of municipalities, regions, we say yes to sustainable management of biomass, but we also say yes to the economic value of the forest. A greater economic value of the forest with these associated strands implies more people in the territories, and more people in the territories means more balanced development. I would therefore like to leave a suggestion here, as Mrs Schmiedtbauer said earlier about the strengthening of the Solidarity Fund. I wanted to say, as they say in my country, that forest fires are not fought, they are avoided, and that is why I would like to leave the suggestion that we have a fund to support prevention in the forest.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Mr President, it is good that we are having a debate on the state of Europe's forests. 40% of the European Union's area is forest and they are extremely important to us in many ways, but now especially from the point of view of combating climate change. Forests bring solutions to the fight against climate change in two areas. On the one hand, they are an important and significant carbon sink, but on the other hand they are also a sustainable source of raw materials. In fact, everything that is now made of oil can be made of wood in the future. It is therefore important to support innovation and product development in the sector. But now that we are talking specifically about forest damage, it is important to emphasise the role of active, sustainable forest management. Forests that are actively managed are not as sensitive to forest damage, storms and pests as untreated forests. And, admittedly, as climate change progresses, various extreme phenomena and storms will also increase in Europe, and that is why we must take good care of our forests. And, last but not least, Commissioner, what we must also improve on at the latest as part of the new forestry strategy is the European database on forest reserves. Once we know the state of our forests, we can also discuss it better at European level. In all countries, statistics are not yet at a level where we have up-to-date information.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: I have already received requests from several people for the procedure for spontaneous speeches that follow. As you know, there is a rule that we can have five minutes of spontaneous speeches. I can also add a few minutes. I therefore am in the 'eight' mind. Spontaneous speeches

name: Balázs HIDVÉGHI
text: – Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable Colleagues, I would like to thank you for your support. In our fast-rushing world, the humility and mindset that foresters have is a great asset. While they care for our forests, which are one of the key to maintaining racial diversity, unlike most of the world, they are not thinking about a one- or two-year perspective, but a 20-30-year perspective. Currently, Hungary a fifth of the area covered by forest. As part of the afforestation programme supported by the Hungarian government, an additional 22 million saplings were planted by our foresters this spring. Our forests not only provide homes, shelters and food for millions of animals and plants, but also actively contribute to the quality of life of the people around them, to the development of the economy and the countryside, and not least to the balance of the climate. Since we are aware that the forest is not only a habitat, not only an economic and environmental factor, but also part of the created world entrusted to us by the Lord God, the Hungarian Government has decided to increase the proportion of hungarian forest land by an additional 6000 hectares... (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Clotilde ARMAND
text: Mr President, I wanted to take the floor to stress that the protection of forests is still at a very low level, it seems to me, on our continent. I take as an example the system of protection of virgin and near-virgin forests. Although these forests represent only a tiny fraction of the forest area in Europe, they are absolutely remarkable in terms of ecological value and conservation. However, significant areas of wild forest continue to be exploited in Romania and Slovakia. To give you an order of magnitude, about 10,000 trees a year are illegally cut down in all Romanian forests. I would like to see one day a European catalogue of primary forests, to recognise their heritage value and provide them with high protection. This catalogue could contain the inventory of these forests that meet the criteria established by a scientific committee, as well as their mapping. I stress a lot about this primary forest catalogue project.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Thank you for your word. Today we are talking about the state of forests in Europe. We all know that forests are our lungs, that they play a very important role in the carbon sink, and that wood products are the right storage of this greenhouse gas.  On the other hand, the situation in Europe is very different from country to country. I come from Slovenia, which is 60% covered by forests, and in Slovenia we have a quality, sustainable way of managing forests, even the percentage and areas of forests are growing.  However, our forests, like others, are sensitive to the many environmental impacts, from fires, snowfall impacts, the consequences of malsolation. We therefore need to strengthen this sector and provide adequate resources in the RURAL development programme, as well as in the LIFE and Horizon programmes, so that we can also manage forests in good quality and responsibly in the future.

name: Mauri PEKKARINEN
text: – Mr President, over the past year, some 15 million hectares of forests have burned in the world. That is more than the area of many Member States of the European Union. These fires have resulted in more emissions than in many countries the emissions from industry and energy production combined. One of the reasons for such a large number of forest fires is that there are quite a few untreated forests in the world. Untreated forests are prone to forest fires. Finland's experiences tell us about this. 60–70 years ago, an average of around 100,000 hectares of forests burned in Finland every year. In the last decade, when we have done good forestry work, on average only about 1 000 hectares per year. My message is that sustainable economic use and management of forests that safeguard biodiversity is an effective barrier to forest fires and is the right and safe path for the climate issue.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Mr President, the Irish Government recently published a plan to create 8,000 hectares of new forestry every year. The target for these newly planted trees is for 70% conifers and 30% broad leaves. This plan will essentially double down on Ireland’s existing commercial forestry policy, which violates the basic principles of biodiversity, with its complete over-dependence on Sitka spruce conifers. Europe does not need factory-farm forests and cash-crop multicultures. We need the right trees in the right places. 42% of all Sitka spruce grown in Ireland is harvested for energy purposes, the rest is used as construction timber. 51% of Ireland’s total forested area is made up of Sitka spruce, therefore an enormous amount of Ireland’s forests are burned as biomass. 42% of all the Sitka spruce grown in Ireland is released back into the atmosphere as carbon. At the heart of the problem is the renewable energy directive: the crazy and completely unscientific policy of treating biomass as having zero emissions or as being carbon neutral. I’d ask the Commissioner to revisit the directive.

name: Marlene MORTLER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which Much important and right has already been said today, and we must all be clear: the European forest certainly cannot save the global climate. Today, however, we are showing that we are serious about talking about the state of the forest in Europe and, above all, looking for solutions. Because the forest is the loser of climate change. When trees die , as has been said several times – they no longer bind new CO2. That is why it is important that we understand the forest as the renewable raw material – a wonderful raw material – that it is, once for protection, but also for use. Finally, I call for us to do everything we can to give millions of new trees in Europe a chance and to encourage the Member States, as part of their European strategies, to put the ball at the top of the agenda.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I am glad that we are working on this important issue compared to others, such as Brexit. I think it is important to show citizens that we are also working on practical problems. I will not repeat here what has already been said, but I would like to stress that we have an instrument that we can use in the framework of forest protection, and these are our European funds.
