I think that we should help precisely in planting forests, trees there, in those Member States where it is needed and, of course, in land consolidation, this has not yet been emphasised here. Our help should be directed to municipalities, regions, but also associations, e.g. associations of private and municipal owners, all this is possible, within the Czech Republic there is such a very strong association. We should also support research against pests that destroy our forests. We have a whole range of tools. I think it is good to use them, and I am prepared to help with this by voting here in plenary.

name: Valter FLEGO
text: Dear Chairman, thank you President, Dear Commissioner, we see what's been happening these past few weeks in the Amazon rainforest. Of course this is the result, first of all, of disregard, that it is terrible, that it needs to react and of course, to act very harshly and very strongly in this direction.  But, however, we should always start from ourselves, see how we can do something good at home. For this reason, of course, we should bear in mind that pollution knows no borders and that climate change knows no borders as well. Nature can do without man, but man can not do without nature and this is clear. For this reason, I am committed to more money in the future financial period for fire-fighting, aushing and for the treatment of diseased forests. In this way, we will invest quite certainly in your healthy present, but also in the future. And that's what we need to do.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the Members for their respective contributions, which reflect the genuine interest in our forests throughout the European Union. The EU is committed to protecting and restoring existing forests, including within the European Union, as confirmed in the recent communication on stepping up European Union action to protect and restore the world’s forests. The sustainable management of our forests can enhance their resilience against extreme events, help confront the climate-change challenge and guarantee the conservation of biodiversity and the provisioning of key services to our society. The future common agricultural policy, with a new balance of responsibilities between Member States and the European Union, will continue to support the sustainable management of the EU forests, based on a needs assessment and a long-term strategy, acknowledging their role in the transition towards a low-carbon and climate-friendly economy, in support of rural livelihoods and the bioeconomy, and in protecting biodiversity and providing ecosystem services. In the light of the commitments made by President-elect Ms von der Leyen in terms of biodiversity and climate change, in the new Green Deal further action could be envisaged in the context of the announced post-2020 biodiversity framework, in order to improve the conservation status and the resilience of European Union forests. We will also consider forest protection and restoration as a specific priority for the future in the context of reflection on the new strategic framework for forests after 2020.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Asim ADEMOV
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, EU forests are our green wealth and perform important environmental, social and economic functions. They occupy over 40% of the EU territory, absorb about 10% of carbon emissions, employ over 3 million people. europeans and have huge potential for the development of the bioeconomy. At the same time, forest ecosystems face increasing challenges related to climate change: extreme droughts, forest fires, floods, landslides, invasive species, pathogens, etc.  As a result of climate change in recent decades, the number and intensity of forest fires has increased throughout Europe, including Bulgaria. Not only the suppression of forest fires, but also the restoration of forests and forest habitats after a fire takes a lot of effort, time and resources. Addressing these challenges requires sustainable forest management, prevention activities and enhanced cooperation between Member States.  In this regard, I welcome the progress made in implementing the EU Forest Strategy and share the need to develop a new post-2020 strategy in order to further improve coordination and exchange of good practices between Member States.

name: Christine SCHNEIDER
text: Writing. – Fires, storms, drought and insect infestations are putting our forests at great risk– so emergency measures are needed. We urgently need a long-term plan to conserve our forests so that our forests can be preserved as climate protectors, recreational areas, habitats for flora and fauna and economic factors. An important point is the strengthening of forestry research in the areas of more climate-resilient tree species and forest plant breeding, strengthening European cooperation in monitoring and combating pests and their spread. It would be a good thing if the nation states cooperated more closely and coordinated their research and results.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Norbert Lins on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development on the patentability of plants and essentially biological processes (2019/2800(RSP)).

name: Norbert LINS
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Barrier-free access to plant materials is a prerequisite for the innovative power of European plant breeders and our farmers, as well as for the genetic diversity of our plants. All members agreed on this at the last meeting of the Committee on Agriculture on 4 September. However, the decision of the Technical Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office in December 2018 jeopardises this barrier-free access. The members of my committee have therefore unanimously decided to send a clear political message. Allow me, as chairman of the Committee on Agriculture and Development of this House, to present the background to this question to the Commission, drawn up by the Committee on Agriculture and Development, in accordance with Rule 136 of the Rules of Procedure. In 2015, the Technical Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office ruled that products derived from essentially biological processes, such as plant seeds, natural features and genes, should be patentable. As a result of this decision, a broccoli and a tomato variety were applied for a patent. In response, Parliament adopted a resolution clarifying patent law for plants in December 2015. This is essentially Directive 98/44/EC, which grants patent protection to biotechnological inventions. The Commission stated in November 2016 that there was no intention to grant patents on natural features. All Member States have supported this interpretation. This was followed by internal powers of interpretation between the Administrative Council of the European Patent Office, which followed the Commission's line, and the Technical Board of Appeal. The latter maintained its position that the patentability of plants should be allowed. The President of the European Patent Office then applied for a final judgment from the large board of appeal of the European Patent Office, which is the highest instance. In this context, third parties are entitled to submit written observations on the facts to the Enlarged Board of Appeal. The deadline for this is 1 October 2019. The Committee on Agriculture and Development has two questions for the European Commission today. Firstly, does the Commission intend to send a written statement to the large board of appeal of the European Patent Office in order to protect the innovative capacity of the Union's plant breeding sector and the general public interest? Secondly, what measures is the Commission taking to ensure that products derived from natural processes are not patentable? Our European plant breeders and agriculture finally need clarity on their future capacity for innovation.

name: Norbert LINS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much for raising this issue because, as was said, it is extremely important to have clarity there. So let me start with the second part of your question, and here the answer is rather simple. The European Commission has taken action to ensure that products resulting from natural processes are not patentable. The Commission has been in close contact both with the European Parliament, the Council, of course, the Member States, and also with the industry stakeholders in relation to the issue of the non-patentability of these products. As requested by the European Parliament in its resolution of December 2015, the Commission adopted in 2016 a notice on certain articles of the Directive on the legal protection of biotechnological inventions. The Commission argues in the notice that plants obtained by essentially biological processes should not be patentable. The Commission notice was unanimously welcomed by the Council conclusions at the end of February 2017, and then EU Member States followed this interpretation in the national laws, and in their patent practices. Now to the first part of your question. Indeed, the Commission, representing the EU, will present so-called amicus curiae observations in the proceeding initiated by the President of the European Patent Office. This will be done before the deadline of 1 October. While the European Patent Convention is not part of Union law, it is in the European Union’s interest to avoid a conflict between the European Patent Convention and the biotechnology directive. The practical effects of the directive would be seriously compromised if the EPO can grant patents for subject matters which the directive excludes from patentability. The substance of the observation will therefore seek an interpretation of the European Patent Convention in line with the directive, as interpreted in the above-mentioned Commission notice from 2016, and thus by the European Parliament, the Council and even all 38 contracting states of the European Patent Organisation. Thus the context of the submission of the Commission will support both the innovative capacity of the European plant breeding sector and the general public interest.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, thank you very much. As a Parliament, at the end of 2015, we clearly demanded that natural planting properties should remain freely available for the development of new varieties. We have said this, and that the patentability of plants obtained through a 'process of an essential biological nature' must be put to an end as soon as possible. This has been resolved, it seemed, at least, by correctly laying it down in implementation rule 28, paragraph 2 of the European Patent Convention, after a good statement on behalf of the Commission in 2016, as you have just said. Unfortunately, one of the multinationals challenged this and a Technical Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office decided on 5 December 2018 that this rule would have been invalid and therefore did not apply. It is inappropriate for the Technical Chamber to try to deal with this issue itself and judged it contrary to the democratic will of the co-legislator, including of this Parliament. It is clear from this statement by the Commission that, in the creation of the European Biotechnology Directive, it was never the intention of the European Commission, the Council and Parliament to enable the patentability of natural properties, of a process of an essential biological nature, or to leave this issue open. It is therefore now imperative that the Commission, this Parliament and the Member States submit their views to the EPO Grand Chamber of Appeal as co-legislator and treaty partner in good time. It is important that we now make patents on plants obtained through an essentially biological process impossible as quickly as possible and defend the right to grow! If the Grand Chamber decides otherwise, the European institutions, as co-legislators, will have to resort to other legal means. We do not tolerate a patent on life!

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, Commissioner, we do not want products from biological processes to be patentable. It is a question of political ethics and an economic issue. We do not want a few wealthy multinationals or rich agri-food groups to pose barriers to plant breeding equipment. We must fight to promote innovation. We are in for the genetic diversity of cultures and we must fight to ensure that the health of European citizens remains a priority. Free access to plant materials is essential for the innovation capacity of the plant breeding sector and European farmers, once again forgotten. These drifts would prevent any breeder from accessing and using existing varieties to create new varieties, but also any farmer from producing his own seeds. I don't want a monopoly of a few large agribusiness groups on the living. Companies whose sole purpose is to make money at the expense of innovation and shared progress.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, with this resolution, I would like to put the patenting of plant properties obtained through classical breeding once again on the agenda. Although the European Patent Office says that it would not issue patents for the time being, there was still a legal debate as to whether or not it should be allowed. This leads to great uncertainty, but also concern among growers and citizens. Planting properties such as the red color of tomato, the taste of sweet peppers or the long stem of broccoli are common in nature. It's crazy, of course, that a company can apply for a patent on that. This is at most discovered and absolutely not invented. Not only am I morally opposed to a patent being pending, I am also very concerned about the consequences when this is possible. I see that there will be a race and that a few companies will get their hands on all the patents and that there will be a monopoly on fruit and vegetables. And that paves the way for extortionate prices on our food.  In addition, it also inhibits innovation, for example that red color of tomato. Other growers cannot continue to digest this and the result is that there is no longer any development of new crops. This is a major risk to our global food supply, as it makes crops extremely vulnerable to new diseases and new pests. I fully understand that companies are keen to commercialise their new crops, only for that is not the right instrument for patent law. The plant variety right is the right to do that. I therefore ask you all for clear support that we, as the European Parliament, can once again send out a strong signal that it has never been our intention that patents can be issued on plant properties and that we do not want to do so now.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which It is actually very annoying that we have to deal with this for the third time here: we had a resolution in 2012, in 2015 and now again, because the European Patent Office is actually ignoring what we want politically, namely no patent on life, no patent on biological processes. The European Patent Office, of course, has an interest in granting patents – and this is quite clear – an economic interest. But here politics, here we have to get on the wheel, so to speak, and the European Commission must now really exert very vigorous pressure, because it is not acceptable for an institution to largely ignore the decisions of the legislator. We now have to decide again on broccoli and tomatoes, but that is a fundamental decision: if we do not now give farmers and small farmers the right to use their varieties, then, and we must see this in the long term, more and more corporations will try to register their patents, to secure their rights to them, and those who actually need it most, namely the farmers and the small farmers, who will then lose their rights. That is why, ladies and gentlemen, it is really crucial now to make it clear at this point: stop, European Patent Office!

name: Ivan DAVID
text: On the group ID. — Mr President, the granting of a patent for a tomato variety and the anti-cancer property of one broccoli variety by the European Patent Office is a violation, firstly, of the UNITED NATIONS Convention on Biodiversity, secondly of the Nagoya Protocol to that Convention, thirdly, of the European Patent Convention and its Implementing Protocol. All Member States are Parties to the European Patent Convention. Each of our countries has its representatives on the Management Board of the European Patent Organisation, which has the power to resolve such disputes around patents issued by the European Office.  That is why we are proposing to call on the Member States, through their representatives on the Management Board of the European Patent Office, to force the Office and its officials, firstly, to revoke patents already granted for varieties and their characteristics, and secondly to ensure that nothing like this ever happens again in the 240 cases negotiated or at any other time.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, it is a stray. Otherwise, I cannot characterize the path taken in issuing patents on plant properties. It gives a limited number of companies powerful monopoly positions. That's what it does. But the price is high, too high as far as we're concerned. Because breeding companies are losing their free access to genetic resources, whereas this free access is crucial for the further development of even better breeds.  I welcome the broad consensus in this House on this issue. Let us send a strong signal to the European Patent Office this week that this misdirected patenting must be abandoned as soon as possible. Of course, intellectual property rights must also be adequately protected in plant processing. But for that we already have a nice and balanced system, namely the system of plant variety rights. Patents simply do not belong in the world of plants. A plant is not an invention, plants are ours. Actually, I have to put it another way: they are part of God's creation and we humans are stewards.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, even if the possibility of patenting varieties obtained without genetic manipulation is not recognised, the truth is that the European Patent Office continues to grant patents on seeds. We see the creation of authentic monopolies in the production processes in the agricultural sector. Multinationals control and divide the market among themselves at the expense of the ruin of many small and medium-sized farmers, the reduction in the diversity of production and the choice of consumers, who have become more dependent on these multinationals. It is one thing to invent genetic transformation processes using molecular biology and intellectual property rights applied to these processes, and another thing is the product, the living organisms, new ones that come from these technologies. It is not acceptable for intellectual property rights to exist over these organisms, as it is not acceptable to patent conventional genetic selection processes, crossing processes or breeding products resulting from such crossings, such as new varieties of plants or animals. Nor are laboratory-assisted selection processes in which whole genomes are involved.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, research and innovation must not be blocked by administrative procedures. The development of any sector in general and agriculture in particular is dependent on research and innovation. Today we are faced with realities that cannot be ignored: the growth of the global population, the limitation of natural resources or their depletion in places, but above all climate change obliges us to act immediately. We need to identify new resources, mechanisms and processes for obtaining food, which must be in sufficient quantities, quality and affordable. In this context, I believe that plants obtained through traditional procedures cannot be patented. The consequences would be disastrous, not only for farmers, who would have to pay extra money for the use of different varieties of plants, but also for research. Today we see that more research is needed than ever. Last but not least, let us not forget consumers. They will be the ones who will finally pay for all these abuses by the European Patent Office.  At the same time, we here, however, do not have to function as firefighters on duty and intervene whenever someone wants to patent a natural process. On the contrary, both we and the European Commission need to send a very clear message: these natural processes through selection and cross-breeding cannot be patented.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, at a time when non-GMO innovation and varietal improvement of plants is the only way to reduce the environmental impact of the agricultural sector, the decision by the European Patent Office is unacceptable to us. We cannot allow the availability of plant material to be restricted or the capacities of our research laboratories to be put at risk, with serious repercussions on the sustainability of our agriculture and the health of all European citizens. That is why, Commissioner, we ask you to act as soon as possible, making the necessary comments to prevent this decision from going against the wishes repeatedly expressed by the co-legislators and to restore the necessary legal certainty, so that agriculture becomes increasingly a protagonist in the fight against climate change and capable of responding, including through the use of new techniques of varietal improvement, ambitiously to the demands of millions of citizens.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. The decision of the Technical Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office to grant patents on plants produced by classical breeding is in no way comprehensible from the farmers' point of view. Free access to seeds is important to me in order to preserve the innovative skills of European plant breeders. I want a diversity of seeds in Europe, and I want small plant breeders to continue to have this access to genetic resources. Free access to seeds is also a key element in breeding new varieties that are better able to meet the challenges of climate change. I therefore hope that the Enlarged Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office will revise the decision so that no patents on plants will be granted in the future.

name: Benoît BITEAU
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the Green Group has always been one of the fiercest opponents of the patentability of life, as Martine recalled earlier. I think on the merits, given the speeches I have just heard, we all pretty much agree. On the other hand, on form, the question remains a little more serious. Who is responsible for establishing the law in the European Union? Parliament and the Council, or the European Patent Office? For the past decade, this organization, under pressure from the United States and major seed companies, has been granting illegal patents for plants, onions, tomatoes, broccoli, and even animals, as recently on salmon. The European Union has certificates of plant breeding. They are far from perfect, but they still allow resistant farmers to sow all species in population, as I was able to do on my own farm. It is also in the light of the effectiveness of the use of these seeds, whose diversity and genetic variability have made it possible to prove themselves, that it was possible, during the debate on the evolution of the specifications of organic agriculture, to show how effective it was.  So at the international level, in all possible forums, the United States, allies of multinationals, are pushing for the bre...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, in 2015 the European Patent Office had deemed it possible to patent plants, such as varieties of tomatoes and broccoli. He then changed his position in the face of the scale of the protests. Alas, on 18 December 2018, its technical appeals chamber ruled in favour of the disastrous position of 2015.  Like the Committee on Agriculture, I ask the Commission and the European Parliament to protest to the European Patent Office. We must clearly reaffirm our absolute opposition to the patentability of life. The public interest must prevail over the special interests of the powerful lobbies at work. Maintaining biodiversity, protecting consumers and defending our farmers depend on us.  Finally, I would like to point out that there has been legal protection for research seeds since 1961. This is the plant certificate, which is much more respectful than the farmers' rights patent.

name: Mazaly AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, in advance I wanted to thank all of you for the minute's silence for the flood victims in my nation, Spain.  Consensus in the Committee on Agriculture demonstrates the need and urgency of this Resolution. It is not permissible that, in the spirit of the legislature, the back door should be opened to plant patents obtained according to essentially biological processes. This disputed decision hurts smaller businesses, but above all innovation in agriculture. However, this error by the European Patent Office and the Court of Appeal cannot serve the most radical groups as an excuse to attack a European patent and variety protection system that works perfectly and guarantees the rights of all operators. A particular error cannot call into question a patent system that promotes the development of our agriculture and currently works efficiently.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Mr President, for some 4 billion years there has been life on earth, and that life is not the property of anyone, and it should not be. The idea that you can patent plants, animals and biological processes is bizarre, but that's exactly what's happening. For example, there is a patent on salmon and trout that are fed with certain plants, which increases the content of unsaturated fatty acids. But those fish and those plants are not invention! These absurd patents lead to the monopolization of our food and endanger food security. However, despite strong resistance from farmers, from citizens, from growers, from the Commission and from this Parliament against these evil practices, the European Patent Office continues to grant patents to food multinationals. That is unacceptable and I ask the Commission: what and how are you going to do to stop this? I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: Madam President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to join the almost unanimous chorus of members who have spoken and who have already expressed their opposition to this truly incomprehensible decision by the European Patent Office. Moreover, this Parliament's position on the patentability of plants obtained by natural and biological methods is clear, and it has been clear since 2015, when this House voted – I would like to remind you – by a clear majority against this type of patent. The Council and then the Commission have spoken along the same lines, and so I do not think there can be any doubt about the political will not to endorse any type of patent on plants obtained by biological processes. Therefore, Commissioner, today we are asking you, we ask the Commission, to make its authoritative voice heard in the final stage of this procedure at the European Patent Office, so that the field of plant selection is protected but, above all, the general interest of European citizens is protected.

name: Karen MELCHIOR
text: Madam President! In 2014, not only did we have elections to the European Parliament in Denmark, we also had a vote on whether Denmark should attach itself to the EU patents. It was a vote that we won and Denmark endorsed. But it was a fierce debate in which I insisted that patents, and what is patented, in Europe do not apply to life and do not apply to plants.  If the EPO has not understood the clear political signals, we need to make it clearer. In Jamaica there is a wild pepper plant that is resistant to different types of pests. This resistance has now been patented and we have not yet had a clarification on it. It is extremely important, not only for our plant producers but also for our European democracy, that we have clarification on this issue.

name: Sarah WIENER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Tomatoes are not machines, and broccoli is not a technical process – there can and cannot be patents on life, on food, on means of life. I was astonished to see the interpretation of the European Patent Office on patent law. As has been said many times, there is a great danger, a real danger, that breeders and therefore farmers will no longer have access to existing varieties. A monopoly of a few seed producers, which have nothing but profit maximisation in mind, can and must be prevented and is totally unacceptable. It is also quite clear to me that the European Patent Office does not express the well-being and the general political will, but rather its own financial interests. I was also very interested to notice that, as an MEP, Mr Wojciechowski, the Commissioner-designate for Agriculture, spoke out clearly against the patenting of plants in 2015. I hereby call on him to take an active part in enforcing Parliament's will and taking action against the European Patent Office in this regard.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, this is an unacceptable and dangerous abuse. Multinational seed companies want a monopoly on living and put forward progress and innovation. It's an excuse. And it's not just a legal problem, it's an ethical and moral problem.  I would like to point out, Commissioner, that at the Council of Ministers on 18 March, many Member States, therefore the majority of European Union governments, expressed their support for the Commission's 2016 interpretive notice, stating that products derived from essentially organic processes should not be patentable.  Finally, products derived from mainly organic processes should not be patentable, it is the best guarantee of permanent availability of all types and varieties of seeds for our farmers.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Madam President, at the end of the debate, I join in the unanimity of this House, of all the political groups present here and all the Members who have intervened; this unanimity was also given in the Committee on Agriculture and, therefore, we want to send the Commission , in this case Mrs Bie-kowska , a clear and unequivocal political message, from the committee and from this House: there cannot be the patentability of plants obtained by biological processes, clearly. And for that they have to intervene, with that claim of the process, before october 1. That is why this oral question, that is why that resolution, is true that thirdly. It is very sensitive, which also shows whether we will have responsiveness to this patent office. I mean, finally, that the general public interest must be preserved and clearly differentiated between protected and patent variety. Parliament's position is clear. I hope that the European Commission will also live up to the circumstances.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I have listened with interest to the Commissioner's position, and I thank her for that. I am glad that there is a general consensus that patent protection in both plant and animal breeding is nonsense. However, we have a dispute with the European Patent Office, which seems to have succumbed to a certain lobby of the breeding society. I therefore appreciate that the Commission's position on this is clear, and the Council's position has also been the same in the sense that we are expressing an appeal here.  So it is up to the Member States to also help enforce this will in the negotiations in the European Patent Office, because the EU Member States have a majority there. I am therefore very much in the hope that this initiative should continue in cooperation with the European Commission - Parliament - the Member States, and I believe that this nonsensical measure will be abolished.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, it’s ludicrous that the European patent authority thinks they can issue patents for plants that are naturally occurring. Here we have natural varieties of broccoli and tomatoes being patented just for more and more profit. Quite frankly, you couldn’t make it up. Multinationals already have enough negative impact on our lives. It would be madness to allow them to monopolise natural life, putting pressure on farmers and commodifying every aspect of our lives. They get away with this already with GMOs, which we should not tolerate either. You should demand that the European Patent Office respect the European Patent Convention which excludes natural life from being patented. Patenting natural life is unthinkable. It is capitalism gone mad.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We sometimes believe in Europe that plant breeding is just a business of large multinationals. This is not the case in Europe at all. Many small players, research institutes and even larger ones are doing plant breeding in Europe, and smaller players in particular need free access to genetic material, which means that they must be able to use all the genetic material available in Europe and in the world to use it for breeding. That is why it is so important that we put a stop to this request to have these varieties patented. I am glad that we are very much in agreement here in this auditorium across the political groups. I believe that we should do everything we can to ensure that life and plants are not patentable, at least if they are traditionally bred. We have our own regulation on genetically modified organisms, which is not up for debate.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all Members for their remarks because I am happy that we are on the same, very unanimous, position. It was very clear from the very beginning in the Commission and the political message that I want to send: that plants obtained by natural biological processes should not be patentable. I can only assure you that we will try and engage in a discussion with the European Patent Office (EPO). We will try to take a very active role to restore, firstly, legal certainty, because we know how important it is for different stakeholders in the sector; then, to preserve, of course, the interests of the European plant breeding sector, farmers, the general public; but to restore common sense. So, thank you very much for this discussion because it gives us yet more strength in our future endeavours.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The debate is over.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The next item is a statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Hong Kong (2019/2808(RSP)). However, before we start the debate, I would like you to listen to me now, to put on the earphones of everyone who did not, because we will be testing a new system in this week's plenary. Catch the eye, i.e. spontaneous questions and blue card questions, i.e. immediately asked questions, would be sent electronically if indicated. The information on the use of the system has already been received by e-mail from all Members, so they can use their request for an opposition using their electronic card. I would therefore also like to ask that if you wish to speak, whether it is a catch the eye spontaneous speech or a blue card immediate issue, please bring your voting card with you.  Of course, this is a test mode, so during the transitional period it will be possible to indicate your need to comment by holding hands or holding up the card, but we would very much like to be able to switch to the electronic system for a more efficient meeting. Thank you very much! So first, during this debate, we will test this electronic system, anyone who wants to speak to it with a catch the eye or blue card, I ask that if he has his voting card, he should do so.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, let me make this initial presentation of the situation in Hong Kong on behalf of the High Representative, Federica Mogherini. Over the past month, the people of Hong Kong have exercised the fundamental right to demonstrate peacefully for their autonomy and the rights of freedom of expression and assembly. Throughout the summer, we invited all sides to reject all kinds of violence and to de-escalate the situation. In this sense, the announced withdrawal of the extradition bill is a step in the right direction. The people of Hong Kong have marched in unprecedented numbers and these massive demonstrations have shown their determination. It is reported that as many as 1.7 million people took to the streets on 18 August this year. In recent weeks, as the situation has escalated, there have been scenes of major violence by triads, apparent attacks on bystanders, reports of excessive use of force by the security forces, petrol bombs and wanton vandalism. All such violence is unacceptable and it cannot be condoned. Nevertheless, the protests have been predominantly peaceful and they continue to be widely supported by the population of Hong Kong. The EU has consistently supported the ‘one country, two systems’ principle. This principle, which is guaranteed in the Basic Law, is also an international commitment from China under the Sino-British Joint Declaration of 1984, as ratified by the Chinese National People’s Congress.  It gives Hong Kong a high degree of autonomy and ensures respect for the fundamental rights and freedoms of Hong Kong’s people. This principle is also crucial for business confidence in Hong Kong, a city which remains an important financial centre and a strategic port and transport hub. The ‘one country, two systems’ principle is essential for Hong Kong to continue fully to play its strategic economic role. The European Union supports the preservation of the rights and freedoms of the citizens of Hong Kong and its high degree of autonomy. This is essential for the prosperity not only of Hong Kong but also of mainland China. Respect for fundamental rights and freedoms and the independence of the judiciary are also vital for the development of Hong Kong, and for the daily lives of its people, and should be upheld in line with the Basic Law and China’s international commitments. On 18 July, the European Parliament discussed the situation in an emergency debate and you adopted the resolution. Meanwhile, the European External Action Service published three statements, and on 17 August the High Representative made the formal declaration, approved by all Member States, rejecting violence and calling for inclusive dialogue involving all key stakeholders. The High Representative discussed the situation with several international partners over the summer and released a joint statement with the Foreign Minister of Canada. Hong Kong was part of the EU Foreign Ministers’ informal discussion in Helsinki at the end of August. Since then, Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced, on 4 September, that the extradition bill, which would have allowed extradition from Hong Kong to mainland China, will be formally withdrawn. This welcome move from the authorities potentially opens up space to work towards a peaceful and enduring solution. However, the situation remains tense. We witness with concern the rising violence in Hong Kong. We maintain our expectation that all sides should refrain from violence and seek solutions through genuine and constructive dialogue. For this to happen, it seems that, first, bold steps may be needed to restore trust. Secondly, we see that business confidence and investment sentiment are also being affected. Hong Kong is a vital bridge between the EU’s economy and China’s. We have a common interest to see the situation evolve positively, including through broad-based dialogue with all key stakeholders to find a lasting and peaceful solution.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: for the PPE Group. – Madam President, thank you for giving your word and also for including this point, because, as the Commissioner said, the situation in Hong Kong is not easy and the fighting is still ongoing. When I saw the coverage of the Hong Kong demonstrations, the thousands of people marching in the streets to maintain freedom, these pictures reminded me of an event 30 years ago in Eastern and Central Europe. Except that back then the dictatorship was being removed, and now we see from China that there is an effort to establish some elements of dictatorship.  As a Christian, I also had to notice the important role of the Christian faith in motivating catholic protesters. In clashes with the police, the demonstrators urged her not to use violence and to sing The Allel to our Lord. These people deserve our support. People who are not afraid to speak out and fight for their human and political rights. They have been demonstrating for months and have pulled out of the controversial law. Opposition to the proposed law would not have been so tumultuous had it not been for the experience of 2015, when China's secret police kidnapped five hong kong bookshop editors who were involved in publishing books about behind-the-scenes intrigues in the Communist leadership of the Republic of China. So the law has been withdrawn, but indignation persists, and it is good that the European Union, the European Parliament, and this debate are sending a clear signal that China must count on human rights to be a condition for any further – and economic – cooperation.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Madam President, the protest in Hong Kong is not drying up, despite the withdrawal by the Hong Kong authorities of the bill authorising extradition. But, it should be pointed out, this project is only part of a claim in relation to the five demands made by the activists.  The millions of people who have been protesting on the streets for three months now are counting on our support, European support. Fundamental freedoms, such as the right to protest or the independence of the judiciary, are and must remain safeguards for defending one state, two systems.  The violence perpetrated by the Chinese authorities against protesters in Hong Kong is totally disproportionate. Excessive use of force is a violation of international norms and fundamental rights.  But we can't just sit around and watch. The Union will always support those who defend human rights and the rule of law by peaceful means. However, it appears that some Member States of the Union have sold technological equipment that has been used to suppress protesters, in particular surveillance equipment and tear gas.  In our 2019 resolution, we called on the EU to set up an export control mechanism to China to prevent European companies and their technologies from being complicit in human rights violations.  Two months later, where are we? The last hearings we conducted in the European Parliament have shown us chilling testimonies today from activists who no longer fear for their freedom but who fear for their lives. What is the concrete message we can give them?

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, 15 weeks: for so long the mass demonstrations have been going on in Hong Kong. With millions of protesters peacefully taking to the streets and campaigning for more democracy, for greater respect, for political rights, as colleagues here have already announced today. And what turns out? What do they get in response? Rubber bullets, repression, tear gas. In short: excessive police force. In addition to intimidation, repression, censorship and arrests.  We must not remain indifferent, and several people have already said this: one country, two systems. It's good that that law has been repealed. But the protesters are asking for more. We must ensure that Hong Kong does not slip into an undemocratic path. We must make it very clear to Beijing that internal affairs are no longer internal when universal human rights are violated. Hence, Commissioner, two very specific questions: how are you going to restart the dialogue with China? How are you going to make it clear to them that we want protests to continue peacefully? How are you going to ask them to finally launch an independent investigation into this excessive police brutality? Demonstrators must be able to protest peacefully and no longer fear for their lives.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, two weeks ago I visited Hong Kong and I talked to actors from different walks of life. I came back even more convinced than before that this Parliament did the right thing when, before the summer, we declared that we stand with the people of Hong Kong. The movement for democracy and freedom in Hong Kong is still going on, and it still deserves our continuing solidarity. ‘One country, two systems’ must not be undermined by intervention from Beijing or by imposing emergency regulations. It is not enough to withdraw the rendition bill. The people want more change. Primarily, they want an independent inquiry into the violence – in particular, police violence – and they want universal suffrage. Universal suffrage was promised to them 22 years ago in the Basic Law. The promise has not yet been kept. Beijing must keep this promise. We, as Greens, support the fight for universal suffrage in Hong Kong. Democracy must win!

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, the European Union, our Parliament, are particularly active in ensuring that democracy is respected in China. It is of course a fine practice to ensure that people's choice is respected and that the manoeuvring and violence that blocks them is denounced. It would be better to look after it in China, everywhere in Europe. In the United Kingdom, a worn-out Parliament opposes a democratic and sovereign decision of British citizens and tries to block their choice to leave the European Union. In Italy, an unnatural political combination is being forced to prevent a return to the polls, which Italians want. In France, an autocratic president, supported by a Parliament that, mechanically, does not represent the popular vote, imposes texts that throw French people, far more numerous than in Hong Kong, on the street. The pension reform project is the latest example. Not to denounce these practices, these manoeuvres, is unworthy of a parliamentary assembly, of our parliamentary assembly. Democracy dies by continuing on this path that excludes the peoples of Europe everywhere.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, we stand by the people of Hong Kong. This has been the continued attitude of the European Parliament since the protests started and since the violations against book-keepers. The people of Hong Kong won their initial battle: the extradition law was withdrawn. Yet all parties should obey the Declaration of 1984 and, in particular, Beijing should refrain from attempts to launch provocations there. We continue to stand by the people of Hong Kong.

name: Idoia VILLANUEVA RUIZ
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, it is already the fifteenth weekend since the great demonstration on 9 June, which marked the beginning of the current crisis in Hong Kong, and that we are seeing how it is ending in different stages of violence. Yesterday we witnessed new scenes of violence, where police resorted to criminal prosecution and water cannons against protesters. We want to be very clear. Today, here, we reiterate our seamless support for the right of manifestation as a fundamental right in all parts of the world. And, in this case, in Hong Kong, as it can't be otherwise. We therefore call for the investigation of police actions as well and the release of peaceful protesters. Fundamental rights and human rights are universal and indivisible. That is why today we also want to denounce here the actions of the Commission and this European Parliament when it sees and denounces the infringement of human rights abroad but looks the other way when it happens on our own territory. The Member States of the European Union have no problem reaching major trade agreements with China. We think it is time for the European Union to have an updated strategic plan with China in its relationship with China. We therefore urge dialogue. We urge the Commission, Parliament and China to guarantee the rights of all people, as well as to establish a European position adapted to the geopolitical challenges of the 21st century.

name: John David Edward TENNANT
text: – Madam President, we either believe in democracy and freedom, or we don’t. If we don’t, this debate is pointless. If we do, then it is a principle that goes beyond national boundaries. In fact it goes beyond European boundaries, it is universal. Violence by the state against protesters is completely unacceptable. Violence by protesters should not get a free pass either. But the issue on its merits is so simple: who should decide who governs Hong Kong? Forget the Qing Dynasty and the 99-year lease, forget the 19th century politics still impacting the 21st – the answer must be that the people of Hong Kong should have the same right to self-determination as every human being deserves.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: – Madam President, the struggle of those who have been peacefully demonstrating on the streets of Hong Kong in recent months is now a struggle for freedom of expression and association, for civil rights and democracy. The European Union cannot therefore remain indifferent to its calls for firm and determined action with local authorities and the Chinese authorities to stop the escalating use of violence against protesters. The European Union must use all the instruments at its fingertips in order to avoid tragic events and to make it clear to the Chinese authorities that the way is not to repression dissenting voices and disproportionate use of force, but to dialogue with a view to peacefully resolving the conflict. We should welcome the calls made by the leaders of the various movements to remain peaceful and to tell the Chinese government that it is not enough to limit itself to declarations of intent and that decisive steps must be taken to respect human rights, the rule of law and freedom of expression and association.

name: Bernard GUETTA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is courage, determination and the eternal struggle for freedom that have just made a very big point in Hong Kong. Not only did the Chinese authorities not dare to repeat the abomination of Tiananmen Square there, but the local authorities, with Beijing's assent, of course, rescinded their decree on extradition to China. We must applaud the Hong Kong protesters and rejoice in this victory, for any setback of a government that is unaware of human rights benefits the freedom of all. However, our satisfaction is not sufficient. We must support the fight for China's freedom, which is and will remain, in any event, one of our major economic partners and one of the great powers of this century. We owe it out of moral obligation, but we also owe it because we can.  We can, because in their tussle with Mr. Trump, the Chinese authorities cannot afford to alienate the Europe they need. We European parliamentarians can because our Assembly is the only institution in the world that is strong enough, independent and united in its defence of human rights to be able to face a regime that has become the largest, most modern and most sophisticated of dictatorships.  We can, finally, because we will soon have the opportunity to demonstrate it by attributing, I hope and calling on all of you, from all political groups, thus awarding the Sakharov Prize to a Chinese opponent in the person of Mr Ilham Tohti, a imprisoned defender of the Uighur people, of whom he is both a child and one of the great figures.

name: Catherine ROWETT
text: – Madam President, in its old objectionable imperial days my country thought of itself as the mother of the free, but whose freedom did that empire guarantee, and where has it gone now? Yesterday, protesters holding Union Jacks demonstrated at the British Consulate in Hong Kong, and rightly so, for Britain surely retains a duty to defend their freedoms accorded in the Joint Declaration of 1984. The recent response from the UK ambassador for human rights seems too sanguine, for the withdrawal of the infamous extradition bill can’t in itself resolve the concerns. If Britain itself will not challenge China’s oppressive response, let us in this European Union step up. Let us be the ones defending human rights without borders and securing universal suffrage for Hong Kong. Let us become truly the mother of the free, and not by building an empire, but by challenging imperial interference.

name: Anna BONFRISCO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Treaties of the European Union unite us all in the inviolable principle of democracy and the rule of law. On the contrary, we see how China tries in every forum, including the United Nations, to diminish people's individual rights, putting the primacy of the state before all kinds of individual freedoms, on the pretext of defending national sovereignty. To say, as Carrie Lam did, that her fellow citizens are a small minority of violent people, without social support, without economic interests, with chaos and threats, worse than SARS or financial crises, is false and deeply undemocratic. The actions of the Hong Kong police and authorities that you have led under the strict control of the Chinese authorities are, to say the least, inhumane. We should respond to this without timidity, with a firm political declaration from the EU, which recognises the speciality of Hong Kong status and guides the perimeter of our future relations with China, in the name of respect for human rights.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, I have a desire to discuss the rule of law and democracy in third countries in this Parliament. However, I invite you all to think about the rule of law that does not exist in the Republic of Croatia. In the Republic of Croatia, 94% of citizens think that Croatia is ruled by corruption, 76% of Croatian citizens believe that we have a bad and extremely bad judiciary. Unfortunately, the monitoring we had when entering the European Union was not enough. I am 21 years in the Croatian judiciary. I have been a judge of the Commercial Court for nine years and I can personally confirm to you that Croatian society is an extremely corrupt society and that we must primarily resolve, in which all institutions of the European Union, including the European Parliament, the rule of law and corruption in our European Union must be involved and then we will have full right to discuss the rule of law in third countries.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, over a million people in Hong Kong have taken to the streets to peacefully exercise their fundamental right to protest. In response, they have been met with brutality, tear gas and rubber bullets. Many have been arrested and injured. Their only crime is a struggle for democracy and human rights. Their values are our values and they’re taking huge risks in endangering their livelihoods and even their lives.  The Commission and the European External Action Service really need to consider all measures in their power to support the people of Hong Kong, who are looking to us with hope, for support and with their demand for universal suffrage. We have the leverage. For example, should we consider the threat of withdrawal of Hong Kong’s financial status as third country equivalence if the Chinese Government takes aggressive action against the protesters and their leaders?  I would like to remind the Chinese and Hong Kong Governments of their obligations to the ‘one country, two systems’ principle – to the protection of civil and political rights in Hong Kong that they signed up to at the time of transfer from the UK in 1997. The EU – especially the UK – has a special responsibility to the people of Hong Kong. We need to act to protect them and ensure that they are given refuge in Europe if they continue to be targeted.

name: Lars Patrick BERG
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Today we are talking about the situation in Hong Kong. I think we all agree that we support the 'one country, two systems' principle for Hong Kong governance. We can all support the statement by the High Representative and the Canadian Foreign Minister when they called on the Chinese Government and the Hong Kong authorities to respect and recognise the Basic Law there, and that only inclusive dialogue can resolve the internal unrest that is now occupying Hong Kong. Calls for an independent investigation into violent incidents, particularly by the police, as now proposed by the United Kingdom, are a possibility to proceed. However, it is also important to ensure that the Chinese Government does not keep pushing the chinese government further and further on the defensive, so that the willingness to engage in dialogue with the concerns of the people of Hong Kong and the international community remains. Strategic diplomacy, which allows the Chinese Government to enter into dialogue without losing face, can hopefully achieve the results that hong Kong's citizens are passionately presented and prevent another terrible disaster, such as that that occurred in Tiananmen Square in 1989.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, thank you very much Madam President, it has been 100 days since the protests began in Hong Kong, the biggest crisis in relations with China since 1997 when, in accordance with the principle of one country-two systems, with broad autonomy Hong Kong was returned to China.  Although, meanwhile, a contentious law that would have made it easier for Hong Kong citizens to extradite china for trial has been withdrawn, protesters continue to fight for an expanded list of their demands at the same intensity. Among other things, they are demanding a greater degree of democratic freedom and the release of thousands of arrested protesters. We are concerned about the increasingly intense violence on the streets of Hong Kong. Hong Kong legislation should act in full compliance with international standards and human rights. Likewise, China has declared itself a signatory to the international framework of respect for human rights in the process of implementing its reforms and increasing global engagement, as it is a signatory to international treaties. First of all, it is necessary to create the necessary conditions for ending violence and to ensure the continuation of dialogue between all key stakeholders. This is the only guarantee for fulfilling the agreements and obligations taken.  (The Representative agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 171(8) of the EEA). Rules of Procedure))

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Chairman, thank you very much.  Colleague Picula, you have succincously described the situation in Hong Kong and given little of this historical review of how Hong Kong's integration into China went, but given that the whole issue of the rule of law and the importance of China as a trade, political and every other partner of the European Union, given the increasing Chinese investments on the territory of the European Union and the Republic of Croatia, as you can see , if you can briefly say, relations between the European Union and China in the future given all these problems you yourself have mentioned?

name: Tonino PICULA
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Chairman, thank you really for asking and I hope that we will all respond together in this term of the European Parliament, answering precisely the question of how and how to deal with the relations of the European Union with all those countries for which there is doubt, justified or that which needs to be proven, that their actions undermine democratic standards.  Will we put the race for profit first, will we put economic interests first, and still put aside some, I would say, the starting and impassable values of the European Union itself. If we really measure both well, we can indeed perhaps influence the improvement of human rights standards in those environments where they are clearly not adequately respected. So it's up to us actually to choose a policy of our own priorities.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, in my opinion, we must support the peaceful demonstrators in Hong Kong, it is the 100 days that have shaken Hong Kong. They have also shaken our confidence in the dialogue that the parties can have to come to a successful solution. The demonstrators protect their right to autonomy, their fundamental right to assembly, which is guaranteed by hong kong's constitution. I am glad that it is the amendment to the Extradition Act that has been withdrawn, but our vote, I think, should support democracy in Hong Kong and peaceful protesters today, because the spiral of violence and provocation that has been spun in Hong Kong is really dangerous. I think that we should support human rights despite certain investments, which has already been mentioned here, because we need to talk about human rights even when we go to delegations to China. Who better to talk than us and not trade human rights for business opportunities, I don't think that suites us.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, along with other British Socialists and Democrats, Labour Party members, students and democracy activists, I signed an open letter to express solidarity with the continuing struggle for democracy in Hong Kong. We support the Hong Kong people’s upsurge against the attacks on their democratic rights, against oppression and inequality. We support the immediate five demands of the movement: for an end to repression, for serious measures to deal with the police state and for democracy, including a government elected by universal suffrage. We call on the labour and trade union movement across the world to organise political and practical solidarity with the Hong Kong struggle for democracy. We support independent workers’ and students’ organisations involved in the struggle. We demand the reinstatement of the Cathay Pacific airline workers sacked for supporting the democracy movement, including their union leader Rebecca Sy and City Legislative Council Member Jeremy Tam. The battle to defend democratic liberties of all workers, particularly migrants in the US and UK, is inseparable from that of our sisters and brothers in Hong Kong now.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, I find a serious lack of balance with this debate. Not all the protests in Hong Kong have been peaceful. Their leadership has close ties to the far right and there has been much foreign interference and disinformation, with millions of dollars flown from the US regime change outfit, National Endowment for Democracy, into the civil society groups at the heart of this anti-China movement. There is even a photo of a protest leader meeting with a US diplomat in Hong Kong. There are legitimate concerns for many of these young people who are on the streets, with their bleak job prospects and rising rents more closely connected to neoliberalism, the financialisation of the city and the domination by oligarchs of their economy and the property sector. Saying that China must meet the demands of this violent foreign-backed anti-China proxy force would just be the EU getting in on the foreign meddling in China’s affairs. Let’s not wear blinkers on this matter.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: – Madam President, I fully agree with what we are saying about Hong Kong, on the defence of human rights in Hong Kong, and we would also want them for China. But I am very sorry that in this song to human rights we forget, for example, something else, which is a paradox. A week ago alone, Mrs. Mogherini was in Cuba, when there was, on the island, a brutal repression, a repressive wave like very few have ever been. And Mrs Mogherini was talking about a great Cuba, a Cuba that would serve as a bridge for the European Union to Ibero-America. A scandal of Mogherini's discourse in Havana, of complicity with the bloody dictatorship that, for sixty years, crushes Cubans, who for sixty years have entered Ibero-America to destabilize and support tyrannies such as Venezuelan or Nicaraguan, and which acts as a general destabilizer. Please, let's be a little more coherent.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, I roundly condemn police violence anywhere, by any state force on any continent, but I have to say that there is something very selective about this discussion on the protests in Hong Kong and indeed the blanket coverage that they are being given across Europe. The issue is being portrayed as a simplistic one with authoritarian China, on the one hand, and people crying out for freedom and democracy on the other.  Nothing is ever that simple and there is plenty of evidence of external interference. Much of the anger in Hong Kong is directed at the fact that the cost of living is astronomical with the highest rents in the world. But I find it a bit intriguing that we have to go halfway across the world to find a place where we can denounce police repression or where we can back democratic rights. Here in France, for example, the behaviour of the police and brutal repression has resulted in hundreds of people securing permanent injuries. We are saying nothing about that. There are political prisoners in jails in Spain, including some of our colleagues here. We say nothing about that.  So, while supporting the release of prisoners in Hong Kong and supporting investigations into violence there, I offer the same support for the European continent – in France and Spain and all the other countries that are trampling on democratic rights.

name: Clare DALY
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I would like to thank Members for their interventions. I think almost all of them were very unanimous and summed up our feeling and approach to the ongoing events in Hong Kong. I want to thank you for keeping the subject at the top of your agenda.  As universal suffrage was mentioned a few times, I would like to remind you that the EU supports the implementation of the Basic Law, which states that universal suffrage is an aim for both the legislative council and chief executive. Such a reform would have to be agreed by all political stakeholders, both in Hong Kong and in Beijing. From this debate and the previous exchange of views that we had in July, we see that the European Union has a strong stake in Hong Kong and is concerned about its continued stability, continued prosperity and, most importantly, the respect of fundamental rights.  We will continue to follow the situation very closely, including the impact on EU residents and citizens and on EU economic interests in Hong Kong. It is more vital than ever to engage in dialogue to bridge the tensions within society for the benefit of Hong Kongers at large and in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region as an international hub.  Allow me, therefore, to again express on behalf of High Representative Mogherini my appreciation for your attention and support in maintaining this important file at the top of your agenda, and I will repeat – as some of you have said – that fundamental rights are universal and should be protected.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The debate is over.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The next item is one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 172 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: 30 years ago, around this time, a little later, the Berlin Wall fell. Both the fall of the Berlin Wall and the fall of the criminal communist regime has indeed opened up new perspectives for all of Europe, especially this Central and Eastern Europe to integrate fully into the European Union. Great progress has since been made. And indeed we can say that the European Union and its extension to the east has indeed been a success. European cohesion policy and European funds certainly contributed to this. Based on the principle of solidarity, european funds from the European budget have indeed enabled central and eastern European countries to be transformed in a large way and to truly co-manage the development of the western and northern Member States. Unfortunately, we are now in a situation to again in some way these differences between east and west of Europe emphasize. We are in a situation where there is talk of a reduction and proposes some reduction in cohesion policy. I don't think we should go in that direction. I think cohesion policy is the success of the European Union, I think cohesion policy is what has enabled those in need, those who are least developed, to get adequate resources, to give them equal chance and opportunity to compete with even the most developed ones and I think in that sense they should go further.  Let us not deny cohesion policy, we work for the equality of everyone in the European Union, let's promote the principle of solidarity because without it the European Union and European integration have no future.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, in this summer of 2019, in the first half of August, a succession of dreadsome fires took place on the island on which I was born and resided, Gran Canaria. With an unquestionable cost, but which has caused forest devastation in a protected environment, absolutely precious natural landscapes. Ten thousand charred hectares, six thousand displaced people. And this is the time to reflect on the limitations of the european Union's recently opened Civil Protection Mechanism, with its European Emergency Response Coordination Centre, to which Spain has generously contributed two aircraft out of the total of seven aircraft and six helicopters made available to this device. Undoubtedly, the Government of Spain has promptly shown in the reply. The Government of Spain mobilized the Military Emergency Unit, which is in these very difficult situations. But there is also a need for a more flexible European response than that allowed so far by the European Solidarity Fund, whose quantitative threshold for access to aid and, above all, the date of regulation, 2002, is crying out for an update so that the European Union can effectively show a solidarity, early and immediate response every time there is a catastrophic fire such as the one that has taken place in Gran Canaria.

name: Klemen GROŠELJ
text: – Honourable Chair, however, despite the intensive efforts made by the Commission and the Commissioner responsible for enlargement to overcome tensions in the Western Balkans, especially in Bosnia and Herzegovina, the situation in the region is not being 200. What is more, we are witnessing further destabilisation of the region and, in this context, stand out, in addition to the institutional crisis in Bosnia and Herzegovina, relations between the Republic of Serbia and Kosovo, where Kosovo's economically excessive and unfounded customs rates are increasingly being exposed as a minestone to any progress in the talks between the two sides and on the way to finding a more permanent solution to this for the region and its future key issue.  I call on the Commission to be more active in the search for an acceptable solution in the light of the upcoming elections in both countries, and, above all, to withdraw those customs duties and, therefore, to open up the possibility of renewing the dialogue and the process of reassuring between the two sides.

name: François ALFONSI
text: Madam President, in September 2013, our Parliament almost unanimously adopted a report of which I was the author on endangered languages in the European Union. In voting on this report, Parliament was addressing the Commission, which has done nothing since, or so little, to the point where multilingualism no longer appears in any of the mission letters of future European Commissioners. Parliament also called on Member States to promote the development of these languages. However, in France, six years later, the European Charter of Regional and Minority Languages is still not ratified. Worse, the education minister who has been in office since the election of Mr. Macron, Jean-Michel Blanquer, has initiated an overtly linguicide policy towards our languages. The European Union has sometimes intervened in favour of respect for human rights in the face of the shortcomings of certain Member States. Respect for the European heritage of our languages and cultures is demanded by our Parliament and by the European treaties. I therefore ask that the French State be formally reminded of the position of Parliament adopted by more than 90% of MEPs in September 2013, and I expect the Commission to do what is necessary to ensure that this European heritage is no longer threatened with extinction.

name: Aurelia BEIGNEUX
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the report of a French association, Future Generations, recognised by the Ministry of the Environment, pointed to an underestimated danger of pesticides in Europe. In particular, the report points to the fact that, I quote: "Pesticide assessment does not take into account all the scientific data, although European regulations require it." It must be admitted that, for European consumers and citizens, confusion is total and legitimate. There is a profusion of conflicting studies and the study of their sponsors suggests that they are oriented or deliberately evade certain data. Finally, there is an urgent need to produce a vast independent study of any financial or ideological interest and, above all, to enable consumers to navigate and be as informed as possible. This study must be as comprehensive as possible, obviously extending it to the endocrine disruptors that proliferate in our daily lives.

name: Krzysztof JURGIEL
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab From 2 January 2019, type C "shopping" visas issued to Belarusian citizens going to The Republic of Belarus Polish. As a result of EU regulations, they can use tourist visas subject to a number of formal requirements: confirmation of hotel reservation, possession of a certain amount of money. As a result, the number of Belarusians from border areas coming for shopping in our region – the Podlasie voivodeship – has decreased significantly. Cross-border trade provides numerous jobs, provides support to residents – this is currently under threat. Consideration should be given to restoring shopping visas or simplifying formalities for tourist visas. Moreover, the new visa restrictions run counter to the spirit and principles of the Eastern Partnership of the European Union.

name: Henrik OVERGAARD NIELSEN
text: – Madam President, following the vote of 17.4 million Britons to leave the European Union, EU leaders stated that they would work to ensure Brexit was not a success. Could that be because if Brexit was a success then other EU members would follow suit?  If we asked the peoples of Europe whether they want a free trade agreement or a political superstate, there would be a massive majority for free trade. But why should the people be given a voice? Democracy is only respected when it gives the right answer.  I come from a background where my father went underground for four years in the Second World War and was the voice of liberation on state radio when Monty liberated our country. I come from a background where my parents started the Danish Eurosceptic movement in the 1960s and I come from a background where I campaigned to halt the oppressive Maastricht Treaty, so I bow to no one in my belief in democracy, free speech and self-government. I urge this Chamber to live up to its initial purpose of being the democratic light-tower of the EU, by not only respecting the British people but respecting those beyond the privileged, unrepresentative, echo chamber of the European Parliament.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, in one minute, I would like to address the colossal conflict of interest of the Czech Prime Minister and the conclusions reached by the European auditors. As you know, the European Commission is dealing with a conflict of interest with the Czech Prime Minister, who, according to their preliminary findings, is also the owner of a large company, which also draws European money from the European budget through a number of programmes.  Already in December last year, Commissioner Oettinger tentatively stated that these programmes continue to be drawn on by this company and continue to be owned by the Czech Prime Minister. Today, european Union auditors identified this connection to the Czech Prime Minister and at the same time identified a number of problematic points in this use of European money. Unfortunately, the Preliminary Conclusions are refused by the Czech Government, and I would therefore ask the Commission to publish the final conclusions, which will be expressed precisely in the case of the audit carried out on the ownership of the Czech Prime Minister vis-à-vis Agrofert.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, low-income groups will be disproportionately affected by any price rises in food. Not my words, but the words from the government’s own no-deal Brexit scenario document. Now last week I attended a meeting of the Bassetlaw Food Bank trustees, where we received reports of demand going up month on month again, where we discussed holiday hunger, kids not getting enough food in the school summer holidays. Now no one in 2016 voted for higher prices at the supermarket checkouts. This is not scaremongering, this is the reality. Now Prime Minister Johnson may or may not have enjoyed his lunch in Luxembourg today, but for families across Britain, the poorest families, those already struggling to make ends meet, his, Prime Minister Johnson’s, reckless careering towards a no deal will make it harder for those families to put food on their table. Let’s be clear.
