No deal will push more families, more kids, below the bread line and for the sake of those parents going to the food banks, literally to beg for food for their kids, no deal cannot be allowed to happen.

name: Vlad-Marius BOTOŞ
text: – Colleagues, the European Union, this wonderful project, this project which, in my view, is the best thing that has happened on this continent, has been speaking for years of the necessary measures to protect the environment. And yet, one of the most important measures to protect European fauna and flora - green infrastructure - has been waiting for years. There are also solutions, punctual solutions. There are many NGOs specialising in this area. There are thousands of passionate specialists who can get to work. From tomorrow. They have experience in implementing many environmental projects and even experience successful projects in partnership between several states. We can no longer wait to see species or habitats disappear. We can no longer wait for the creation of national agencies or institutions. It is time to ask the European Commission to open the funding lines for these NGOs and give the green light to people to get to work. And we must here, from this forum, at European level, make these funds open as soon as possible for the implementation of projects and address all environmental actors as well. I think the time has come to call for less discussion and more action.

name: Catherine ROWETT
text: – Madam President, after more than 30 years Japan has recently resumed its outrageous practice of commercial whaling, which is in breach of international law and undermines the protection of biodiversity and marine ecosystems. This Parliament has repeatedly called on the Commission to engage with Japan with a view to abolishing this practice, and it is deeply regrettable that the EU-Japan free trade agreement does not contain any specific provisions on whaling. However, we cannot stand back and allow the slaughter of whales for profit to continue.  For this reason, my party colleagues and I have written a letter to the Commissioner for Trade questioning whether Japan’s actions comply with the sustainable development chapter of the trade deal. If not, we call on her to initiate enforcement procedures immediately. We must stop celebrating trade deals when they clearly betray even the best of our environmental practices.

name: Guido REIL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which It's nice that we get to know each other. I'm new here, and I wonder about a lot of things. I was particularly surprised by what I found in my apartment in Brussels in a new building: a light bulb. The elders of us may remember that exactly ten years ago the light bulb was banned here. Before that, it illuminated us with its warm light for 130 years, and we banned it. At that time, consumers were being forced to use energy-saving lamps. Energy-saving lamps actually save energy, but mercury is in it, and mercury is not necessarily good for the environment. So the people of Brussels are sympathetic to me; they have common sense, as I have already noted. Brussels is not very much of the European Union's obsession with regulation and prohibition, and I think that is a good thing. Because we have mature, enlightened citizens in Europe, and these mature and enlightened citizens should also have the freedom to decide for themselves what they buy and how they live in a free Europe. Good luck!

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Dear Madam President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable Members, I would like to draw your attention to an outrageous intention by the German volkswagen company to make new investments at its plant in Turkey. This is the same Turkey that arrested and imprisoned journalists. This is the same Turkey that does not use any environmental norms. This is the same Turkey that violates its association agreement and implies and offers illegal State aid to this plant. This is the Turkey that threatens and blackmails the European Union into letting in illegal migrants. In this Turkey, the German company Volkswagen wants to move its second largest plant to Europe. It's outrageous, it's dishonest, it's wrong. I ask you, both the Commissioner and the Prime Minister of lower Saxony, and ask him when he is sincere. Then when they talk to us about rights, they come to Sofia to lawyer any disgraceful fights, or when somewhere rights are violated, but the company will export money there. I appeal to both the current Commission and President Von der Leyen and the future Commissioner for Competition, and I urge the European Commission to rule and not allow this deal to take place – European money to be exported to an Islamic state and to fund erdogan's regime.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we talk every day about democracy and human rights in the European Parliament. That is why I chose today to talk about where respect for it is completely lacking. I am referring here to the self-proclaimed Transnistrian region.  Less than 100 kilometres from the eastern border of the European Union, the Russian Federation is waging a war on human rights. There, the Romanians, the majority being, are blatantly discriminated against. I can tell you this because I've been there so many times. Moreover, I am one of the few European politicians with a ban on entry into the Russian Federation. Precisely for the uncomfortable views I have expressed towards the Russian leaders, who have chosen to trample on the fundamental rights and freedoms of these citizens.  Now, as a Member of the European Parliament, an indisputable promoter of democratic values, we have an obligation not to abandon the citizens of this area. I therefore call on the European External Action Service to document and draw up a thorough report on human rights violations in this region illegally occupied by the Russian Federation, part of the Republic of Moldova. They're going to discover a lot of interesting things.

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, while we are talking about sustainability and biodiversity, Europe itself is currently facing the extinction of some species that could be saved if we took urgent action. One of the most affected is the Danube sturgeon. On the Romanian portion of the river, this fish, which survived the dinosaurs, now disappears. It continues to be aggressively fished by Ukrainian fishermen who are not subject to European Union rules and are at risk of climate change and dams that are built upstream.  Thus, of the six species that Romania had, two disappeared, and in the case of the other four, at the last count, the specimens were recorded in unexpectedly small numbers. For example, nine males were recorded in one count and no female in one of the types. Although there are many European conventions, they do not seem to work and the economic and social damage is extremely great. I therefore urgently call on Parliament and the European Commission to consider much tougher measures to save the sturio, funding and additional solutions for perpetuating this species before it is too late.

name: Nicolae ŞTEFĂNUȚĂ
text: – Madam President, the fight against climate change also depends on the rule of law and its respect. And I will give you two examples today that show that sometimes even the rules of the European Union, secondary rules, do not fully comply with Article 11 of the Treaty. This article provides for a cross-cutting obligation for the Union to take environmental impact into account in all its policies.  The first example is the mobility package, which obliges vehicles to return home. This would lead to a dramatic increase in goal races. According to Eurostat, 22% of all freight vehicles in the European Union will be empty flights. This will mean a significant increase in carbon dioxide emissions.  The second example, and this very important one, and my colleague Vlad Botoş, referred it to, the Union does not allow access to justice before the Court of Justice of the European Union for NGOs, in accordance with Article 9 of the Aarhus Convention. So, if we are to fully respect our desire to stop the effects of climate change, we must start at home, including in compliance with international law.

name: Diana RIBA I GINER
text: – Madam President, three of Altsasu's eight young people in Euskal Herria add up to more than 1,000 days in prison. They are in prison simply because they were involved in a fight involving members of the Civil Guard who were off duty. The prosecutor claimed it was a terrorist attack and, although the National Court dismissed these charges, he convicted them of severe crimes ranging from two to thirteen years in prison. In 2017, fifty-two MEPs requested President Juncker's intervention, and Vice President Timmermans announced that they would closely monitor the case. Amnesty International also noted the risk of ambiguity in the charge of terrorism and expressed concern that defendants were being discriminated against for their ideology. The day after tomorrow a new hearing is planned and from here we ask the new Commission to follow the case carefully and take the necessary measures if the Spanish State does not act in accordance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am addressing President Sassoli even though, despite his role as President of Parliament, he is not here now. However, I have followed your statements closely since the beginning of your inauguration and I have to say that I have caught a real obsession with immigration. He said before that he was in favour of NGOs, without taking into account the fact that they actually facilitate the smugglers; he said that it is necessary to welcome immigrants, without considering that most of them, those entering Italy, are illegal and have no right to be accepted; it has attacked the policy of closed ports, after years in which Italy, thanks to the left, has become the refugee camp throughout Europe. I would have expected more moderation from the President, not pro-immigration cheering without any brakes. I have to say that I have seen the same attitude on the part of the President of the Commission. I have only heard goodness, empty words, commercials, after years of absolute nothing on the part of Europe. We simply want a Europe that is less focused on talking about fake integration and more focused on defending its borders, just as Salvini does in Italy. I will conclude by saying that we are tired of a Europe that has been criticising Italy for months and that has not helped our country in the slightest. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, I would like to draw attention to something that we all know, but we are not discussing. It is about the fact that, in recent years, the European Union has become less and less relevant in global foreign policy and global decisions. I call for a debate in the European Parliament, in the Committee on Foreign Affairs - AFET, in the European Commission, a debate on solutions for the European Union to become a global power pole, as it can be, together with the United States, China and the Russian Federation. In the absence of such an objective, we risk becoming a political and economic area that will receive the effects of globalisation, without participating, on behalf of the 500 million Europeans, in the decisions on the direction that globalisation is to take. For this reason, I believe that we have an obligation to respond to the interests of the 500 million (the President interrupted the speaker)... Europeans, participating in the decisions that shape the process of globalisation in the future.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, today I would like to raise the alarm about trafficking in human beings, trafficking in minors, trafficking in women for prostitution. They are cross-border networks. That is why I have allowed myself to make a letter to the President of Parliament, but I also ask the Commission to intervene urgently through the agencies we pay from the European Union budget, such as Europol, and to make an inquiry in all the Member States, because a single state will never be able to solve these human trafficking networks, human trafficking networks. I must stress that the European Union also means the security of citizens. Citizens' rights, human rights also mean security. I must also say that children's rights are also not respected, and I have a concrete example in the very country holding the Presidency, Finland. Institutionalised children do not have the right to make their point, although the law states that at twelve years of age they can go to court. This is the case of Doctor Simimal, with two children. He's been struggling for three years. We must, however, think not only of economic development, not only of other things, but also of the defence of human rights.  I must say that respect for human rights must be analysed not only in the eastern countries, because trafficking is from the east to the countries of the west. I therefore call for this inquiry in all Member States.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support As a Member of Sopron, allow me, above all, to commemorate the 30th anniversary of the Pan-European Picnic. 19 Here, 30 years ago, we Sopronians, but also my fellow Members from post-communist and Western countries, could benefit from the pride of being part of the creation of freedom and unity 30 years ago. It is very interesting that 30 years later, this unity, the political, moral and social horizon that we opened up at that time, tolerance, equality and freedom seem to be disappearing, and the European Union is heading for disintegration, if not otherwise, economically anyway. There are 120 million poor people who do not have basic sanitation conditions for housing, such as toilets, sewerage systems or clean drinking water, and I think that this issue should fit into the first 100 days of the Von der Leyen Commission. In our democracies today, if we cannot find a remedy for pan-European poverty, then in fact our democracies are toothless lions who cannot do anything about their fundamental interests to their citizens. Not to mention the fact that, economically, this is very much a step backwards for the European Union. Thank you so much. I ask that we do something about poverty in Europe, as we did 30 years ago.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: – Madam President, colleagues have probably heard of the smear campaign against judges critical of the Polish Government, the so—called Piebiak scandal. Łukasz Piebiak was Poland’s Deputy Minister of Justice, who resigned after a news portal published communications via WhatsApp and Facebook Messenger. These communications could be evidence of a campaign of intimidation, coordinated from within the Justice Ministry, against judges resisting government efforts to take control of the Polish judiciary. Nemo judex in causa sua, but the General Prosecutor is, at the same time, the Minister of Justice and supervises their proceedings. It is high time to set up a special inquiry committee within this Parliament in order to ensure independent proceedings in this matter.

name: Juan Ignacio ZOIDO ÁLVAREZ
text: – Madam President, Spain has just suffered one of the worst floods in its entire history, which has affected Andalusia, the Region of Murcia, the Valencian Community and Castilla-La Mancha. Communications by train, plane and road were cut off. Substantial material damage and crop losses have been accounted for. Thousands of people have had to be evacuated from their homes and, unfortunately, we have suffered the loss of human life. It is now that Europe must show its solidarity with the thousands of Spaniards who have suffered the consequences of the floods. I would like to take this moment to express to all of them our support and hand to solve the consequences. Likewise, the recognition of all those who have intervened in the various operatives. That is why, Madam President, I urgently call for the activation of the European Solidarity Fund. Europe must contribute to all the resources in its power to alleviate the damage of a truly dramatic situation and help bring everything back to normal in the shortest possible time.

name: Ibán GARCÍA DEL BLANCO
text: – Madam President, the fight against climate change or the substitution of traditional energies with renewable energy is, of course, a game which the European Union and humanity itself are playing and in which their own survival is also played. But it makes no sense for that game to be supported only by some regions of Europe. There are many countries — most countries — which, in accordance with the Union's own approaches, are carrying out this task and are also speeding up the procedures for making this substitution. And many of them have also put forward economic and social conversion procedures in these own regions, but the truth is that up to this point they have not been particularly successful. It is high time for the European Union itself to become much more involved, in addition to the national governments themselves, and to seek to provide funds, not only sufficient financial funds, but also expertise, also advice for the implementation of these funds. I believe that the time has come for the Union itself, in the next financial perspective, to provide sufficient funds, not just patches, in the forthcoming financial perspectives. Of course this European Union was industrialized and Europe industrialized with coal. The European Union, its germ, also came around coal; entire generations of Europeans and Europeans have given up their health, left their lives around coal. I think we are faced with a question not only of social justice, but also of justice with history.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: – Madam President, we take peace for granted in the European Union and think that we are no longer in danger of a real hot war. It's not like that. 80 years ago, Europe was engulfed by the Second World War, which is said to have been essentially, after a 20-year pause, only a kind of continuation of the First World War, the causes of which have not been eliminated. The infestation of Poland by Nazi Germany on 1 September 1939 is considered the beginning of the Second World War, although it has been fought elsewhere before. Less is already being said about what preceded poland's assault. It was not just the condemnable Ribbentrop-Molotov pact that we will be talking about a lot in the coming days, and which has caused a lot of bloody and negative events in Europe. Let us not forget, however, the Munich Agreement, the so-called 'Munich Agreement'. The Munich dictatorship, which took place less than a year before Poland was invaded, in which Europe's largest democracies, Britain and France, loosened their hands to Hitler to break up Czechoslovakia and take up a large chunk of its territory. Since then, the reinforced Hitler has managed to continue his Drang nach Osten much more easily. It was a betrayal, and even sacrificing a democratic Czechoslovakia did not prevent war. I would like to say: let us keep this in mind, it is a memento for us, and finally I just want to stress that today war is no longer a profitable business, but only peace does not guarantee us peace. We must strive to further promote and defend this peace.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Madam President, throughout the European Union governments are making reactionary changes to the laws on the functioning of trade unions. In Greece, the New Democracy government is trying to impose a trade union law, which includes electronic registers in trade unions – workers' file. It circumvents their statutes, introduces electronic voting for the strike, hitting collective living procedures, bringing about the abolition of the strike right and continuing the unpopular policy of the previous government, which paved the way with obstacles to strike. Similar measures apply in other Member States of the European Union, such as Italy, Britain, Belgium and Sweden. The European Union, its capital and its governments are strengthening the anti-labour offensive. They are concerned about the possibility of a new capitalist economic crisis. They are preparing by strengthening the suppression of labour struggles, undermining trade unions and racing claims, trying to pass the social partnership dangerous to workers. Workers resist these anti-labour methods. They organize their fight, as is currently the case in Greece. They are massively opposed to government policy. They are fighting for racing unions that will defend labour rights and clash with the forces of capital and their power.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The next meeting will take place tomorrow: Tuesday, 17 September 2019, 9.00-14.00 and 15.00-21.00 The agenda has been published and is available on the European Parliament's website. The meeting is adjourned.
